direction.raw_text: . DAY. A ROADSIDE/COACH. The sun is higher in the sky. Jane exhausted, now running down a main road. Her spirts lift at the sight of an approaching coach. She flags it down. Jane empties her purse into the driver's hand. He looks at her money then suspiciously back at her. A terse nod indicates she can get in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane sinks into a dark corner. Her fellow passengers look shocked by her dishevelled appearance at such an early hour. She undertakes a tremendous effort not to betray her emotional state. She doesn't sob, she doesn't howl - although her breathing threatens to. Slowly, unable to bear the day, she closes her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. WHITCROSS. Sunset. A whitewashed, stone pillar set up where four roads meet on a barren moor. The coach driver opens the door. With a curt nod he indicates that Jane must get out. She looks around, dismayed. In each direction there is open moorland for as far as the eye can see. The driver sets off at a good pace - glad to be rid of such a passenger. Jane puts her hand to her side for her bag of belongings. It is not there. She runs as fast as she can after the coach. It is receding towards the horizon. She comes to a halt, objectless, lost, alone. She pulls her knitted shawl around her. She leaves the road and sets off across the moor, into the gathering dark. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 2.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THE MOOR. Jane is on her knees by a strange overhanging rock. The night sky is awesome; the universe is all around her. She is trying to calm herself with a prayer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THE MOOR. Jane lies on a great rock, soaking up the heat of the sun. She is like someone numb with pain. She watches a lizard crawl over the rock. She is mesmerised.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THE MOOR. Jane squats in the heather and eats bilberries as the light fades. She hungrily licks the juice from her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. THE MOOR. Jane is asleep in the heather, her shawl wrapped around her. A red-haired child in a white nightgown lies by her side, watching her. It is Helen Burns. Helen reaches out. She touches Jane's hand. Jane wakes. She sits up. She is alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. BY A RIVER. Jane is crouched on a rock watching the waters go by. The sky is overcast. The first big drops of rain land on the stones. Jane makes no movement. A raven lands on a rock nearby. Jane is suddenly filled with a wild rage. She picks up a stone and hurls it at the bird with a raw cry. The gesture exhausts her. She watches the bird wheel away, as the rain starts to pour.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . A FARM BY A WOOD. It is raining hard. Jane sees a small girl come out of the farm with some leftovers. She drops them into a pigpen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane leaning into the pigpen. She picks a stiffened mould of porridge out of the mud. She lets the rain wash it. She eats it ravenously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEXT DAY. A WOOD. It has stopped raining. Jane is huddled under a tree. She is shaking, shuddering. The life has gone out of her eyes. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 3.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THE EDGE OF THE WOOD. The moors rise away above her to the horizon. Jane looks up at the sun starting to set. The clouds are red and gold. She sees a small red-haired girl in a white nightgown walking barefoot on the moors ahead of her. The girl turns, looks back at Jane. With her last strength, Jane follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THE MOOR. Dark clouds are banking up; the rain starts again. Jane is struggling through a marsh. Her boots are stuck. She falls. Her hand disappears into mud; her face pressed against the earth. She doesn't move. She has reached the point of despair. The girl's bare feet walk close by, as if waiting for her. Jane looks up. Where the child should be, she sees a light shining across the moor. Jane starts crawling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THE MOOR/MOOR HOUSE. Jane is toiling on through the lashing rain towards the light. It has become a window. A brief flash of lightning shows her a low stone cottage. Helen Burns is sitting on the gate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane is crawling through the narrow garden. On her knees, she peers through a window. On either side of a bright little fire sit two young women. They look exactly like Jane; slight, neat, dressed in black. One, Diana, has her hair slightly curled and hides her gentle eyes behind spectacles. The other, Mary, is very young; no more than seventeen. Each has a book on her knee. They are talking intimately. They look so close, so loving and the room looks so cosy that it pains Jane considerably.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane knocking at the door. Hannah, an old servant answers. She is suspicious; Jane looks like a wretch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want? Jane manages to find her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shelter. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 4.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can't take in vagrants. Here's a penny. Now take it and go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no strength to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can move off. And if there are others with you tell them we are not alone. We have a gentleman here, and dogs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But I must die if I am turned away. The door slams shut. Jane lets out a hopeless wail.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God help me. I will die. She turns away, her hope gone. As she collapses, she finds herself supported by a strong pair of black-clad arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All of God's creatures must die. But not prematurely - and not on my doorstep I hope. Jane is lifted up. She finds herself looking into the face of the handsomest man she has ever seen; St John Rivers. He lifts her over the threshold into the warmth of Moor House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MOOR HOUSE - THE KITCHEN. A fire is roaring in the stove. Hannah is bent over it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've had a beggar woman come, Mr Rivers. I sent her - For shame! Hannah falls silent as she sees Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You did your duty in excluding her. Let me do mine in admitting her. He sets Jane down before the hearth. She can barely stand. She is soaked to the bone, filthy with mud. Her skin has a ghastly pallor. Diana and Mary enter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John, who is it? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 5.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know; I found her at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought her one of the gypsies from the cross.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's as white as death. Jane can hold herself up no longer. Diana moves forward. She and St John catch Jane and help her into a chair. The rain hammers on the windows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hannah, some water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's worn to nothing. She looks like a spectre. St John, if you hadn't taken her in, we would have fallen upon her dead body in the morning.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's no vagrant; I'm sure of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's milk and bread for you. Jane tries to mouth her thanks. She sips the milk. Eats a mouthful of bread. Diana kneels at her side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ask her her name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: - I am J - Jane cannot speak. She's incapable of uttering her own name. She hears John Reed's voice calling from far away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, tell us how we may help you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can we send for anyone? Who are your people? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 6. The questions are deeply troubling to Jane. She is losing consciousness. She sees an image of a small girl of ten, running away through a great darkening room. Jane tries to follow her. The action draws her up out of the kitchen chair. She hears John Reed's voice again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Jane Eyre! Where are you? Jane, panicked, looking for somewhere to hide, passes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - A GRAND RECEPTION ROOM. Rain hammers against the windows. Jane aged ten, looking hunted, runs in looking for somewhere to hide. She springs behind a curtain. John Reed enters; a fourteen year old, his stomach bursting out of his fancy clothes. He is holding a riding crop as if it is a sword.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come out, rat. I know you are in here. Come out now and I won't punish you. Jane watches him pass by her. He practises a perfect lunge.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rat. He exits. Jane breathes a sigh of relief. She slowly pulls the curtain across, making the window a private sanctuary. There is a book lying on the seat. She opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane is sitting cross-legged, completely absorbed in her book - a beautifully drawn picture of a cormorant. She runs her finger over it. We hear the sound of great waves plunging on to a shore.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. AN ARCTIC COAST. Jane, aged ten, is sitting cross-legged on an isolated rock, her eyes locked with those of a stooping black cormorant. St John's voice comes from a long way away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Diana, Mary help me get her upstairs... The cormorant raises its wings like a great black cloak. Jane watches as it takes off and flies away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 7.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE WINDOW SEAT. Jane has her eyes closed. A great Atlantic wave hits the sash window behind her, drenching it with foam and brine. Suddenly the curtain is pulled back. John Reed stands in front of her. Jane shrinks back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have been looking for you these last ten minutes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you want?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Say forgive me, Master Reed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have done nothing wrong. Master Reed. John grabs the book.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who gave you permission to read my book?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wasn't aware it was yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everything in this house is mine. You're lucky to live here with gentleman's children like us. Your father had nothing. You should go and beg. Jane stares him out. John can sense her contempt. He belts her with the book. Jane hits her head on the window clasp, drawing blood. She is shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for the look you had on your face. You bad animal. Jane snaps. She throws herself upon him, the rage in her released; pummelling, scratching, hurting him in any way she can. She is barely coherent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wicked and cruel - you are a slaver - a murderer -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall tell mother -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hate you John Reed. I hate you - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 8. John is flabbergasted. Like all bullies, he is terrified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mamma! Mamma! There's a rat! Rat! Jane bites him. Hard. At that moment, Mrs Reed appears on the scene. John screams. We see Mrs Reed's shocked face. She is an overweight woman pushing forty in a bright, elaborate dress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MOOR HOUSE - A BEDROOM Dinah and Mary are gently taking Jane's soaking clothes off; one at each side of her. Jane is distressed, approaching a delirium. She resists them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. GATESHEAD - THE RED ROOM. Jane is carried in and set down on a footstool by two servants, Miss Abbot and Bessie - one at each side of her. She is still resisting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For shame, hitting your master.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you don't sit still you must be tied down! The fight goes out of Jane. She sits, defeated. Bessie, young and plump, quickly wipes her bleeding forehead. She has some compassion. Miss Abbot has none.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What we do is for your own good. If you are passionate and rude like this, your Aunt Reed will send you away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're worse than us servants. We work for our keep; you do nothing. Pray for forgiveness Miss Eyre or something bad will come down that chimney and fetch you away. The door slams. They are gone. Jane slowly grips the edge of the stool. The room is chill, silent. Red walls and curtains, murky in the fading light. In front of Jane, a stone fireplace gapes like a mouth. Beside it, a full length looking-glass in which her pale reflection stares out. Behind her, a bed supported on pillars of mahogany, hung with red. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 9. The piled up pillows and mattresses glare in cold white. Jane's breathing is the only sound in the room. A sudden gust sends rain pelting against the windows like fingernails. A distant moan of wind seems to breathe out of the black hearth. Jane reverts her nervous gaze to the pitted mirror. Her eyes lock on the small figure trapped in the mirror's visionary hollow; her white, bleeding face, her eyes glittering with fear. It is a phantom. The eyes are black, the skin a deathly grey. Blood. Jane's breathing becomes choked with terror. She can't get her breath. We hear blood rushing through her ears. It sounds like the beating of great wings. Slowly, a light appears over her. It may be something shining in from outside. But to Jane it seems as if it is surrounding her, enveloping her. The figure in the looking glass opens its mouth. The scream, held in so long, finally rips from Jane's throat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. GATESHEAD - THE FIRESIDE. At the sound of the scream, Mrs Reed, slumbering, almost jumps out of her skin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. GATESHEAD - THE KITCHEN. Miss Abbott almost drops the tea tray she is carrying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. GATESHEAD - A CORRIDOR. Jane is banging on the door, screaming, hysterical with terror. Bessie rushes to the door and unlocks it. Jane flies into her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Eyre what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bessie!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you seen something?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There was a light. We see Bessie's own fear as she glances into the dark room. Mrs Reed is storming towards them, furious.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bessie, I gave orders that she was to be left in the red room until I came. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 10.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But she screamed so loud ma'am.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is play-acting. Let her go. I know your tricks Jane Eyre and I abhor such artifice. Loose Bessie's hands, child. Mrs Reed prises Jane away from Bessie as she speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You will now stay here an hour longer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No - Aunt, have pity -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And only when you are perfectly submissive will I let you out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please - I cannot bear it -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence. This violence is repulsive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall be killed -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have mercy, have mercy I beg you - Mrs Reed throws her back into the room, slams the door and turns the key. We hear Jane's unspeakable howls of terror, her anguished bangs upon the door. Bessie is looking at Mrs Reed aghast. Mrs Reed withers her with a frozen glare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. GATESHEAD - THE RED ROOM. We see Jane in her distress, hitting her head on the door. She falls back. On the floor, her arms and legs move beyond her control. She is having a fit. When it is over, we see Jane unconscious. She is lying in a pool of ghostly light.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MOOR HOUSE - A BEDROOM. Through the light, Jane sees Mary and Diana Rivers at her side. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 11.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's awake. St John approaches in his parson's collar, blocking out the light as he looks down. Jane gazes at him remotely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure we'll find she's simply had a misunderstanding with her people. I hope she's not done anything deplorable; there's nothing so sad as a fallen young woman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at the suffering in her eyes. They're like dark pools - Diana smiles at Mary's tendency to over-dramatise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has a peculiar face; I rather like it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's not at all handsome.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's so ill, St John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ill or well, she'll always be plain. Jane's eyes slide away from him and close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE MORNING ROOM. A bright morning. A huge clergyman dressed in black is staring down at Jane, blocking out the sun. We see him from her POV; his expansive chest, dramatic facial hair, huge flared nostrils, frowning brows. He is Brockelhurst, the epitome of grim.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no sight so sad and so deplorable as that of a wicked little girl. Do you know, Jane Eyre, where the wicked go after death?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They go to hell.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what is hell, can you tell me that? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 12.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A pit full of fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And should you like to fall into that pit and be burning there forever?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What must you do to avoid it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must keep in good health and not die. Mrs Reed is by the fireside in an ultra-feminine dress. She puts down her tea cup in irritation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been her sole benefactress and her kindest friend. But she shows no gratitude and brings nothing but discord into my house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is her parentage?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's an orphan. Her mother was my late husband's sister. On his deathbed he exhorted me to care for her. I have always treated her as one of my own. Jane silently revolts against this lie.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you accept her at Lowood school Mr Brocklehurst, keep a strict eye on her. Her worst fault is a tendency to deceit. I'm sorry to tell you that Jane Eyre is a liar. Jane's eyes flash with outrage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All liars will have their portion in the lake burning with fire and brimstone. She shall be watched, Mrs Reed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish her to be made useful, to be kept humble. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 13.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can rest assured dear lady that we mortify our girls in the sentiments of vanity and pride. They are taught to be quiet, plain and modest. A passion of resentment is forming in Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shall root out the wickedness in this small, ungrateful plant. Mrs Reed smiles sweetly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And as for its vacations, it must spend them all at Lowood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE ENTRANCE HALL. Jane is climbing the staircase. John Reed blocks her way.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So, Rat, you're being sent away. It's as I thought; you're not fit to associate with me. Jane snaps. She cries out:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are not fit to associate with me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE MORNING ROOM. Mrs Reed is at her desk. Jane appears in front of her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said I was a liar. Well I am not. If I was, I should say that I loved you and I don't. I dislike you the worst of anybody in the world except John Reed. He is a liar, not I.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How dare you speak in this manner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll never call you Aunt again as long as I live and if anyone asks how I liked you I'll say that the very thought of you makes me sick. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 14.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wouldn't dare.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll remember how you thrust me back into the Red Room and locked me there to my dying day. Even when you knew it was haunted and I begged to be let out. People think you are good but you are bad and hard-hearted and I'll let everyone at Lowood know what you have done!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Children must be corrected for their faults.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Deceit is not my fault!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you are passionate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My Uncle Reed is in heaven and can see all that you do and think; so can my mother and father. They know how you hate me and wish me dead. They can see. They see everything you do and they will judge you, Mrs Reed. Mrs Reed has turned quite pale. Jane blazes with victory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE GATE HOUSE. Bessie is waiting with Jane while her belongings are loaded onto a public coach, its top laden with passengers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're such a queer, solitary little thing. If only you could make yourself more appealing. Perhaps if you tried smiling from time to time, people would find you more pleasant -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't scold me Bessie. I know you dislike me -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't dislike you Miss; I'm fonder of you than of anyone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You don't show it. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 15.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Jane - Jane throws her arms around Bessie and embraces her with great force. Bessie returns the embrace, surprised, moved. Jane gets into the coach. Bessie looks up at the driver.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You take good care of her. Jane's small, pale face peers out of the coach window, watching Gateshead recede. She doesn't cry. But Bessie can't stave off her tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. LOWOOD - THE HALL. Jane, half asleep is carried out of a coach and into a howling gale. She is taken under a stone inscription: `Lowood Institution'. She is set down in front of a woman with striking features and intelligent eyes; Miss Temple. She bends down and looks into Jane's face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's your name, child?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are very young to be sent alone, Jane Eyre. She gently touches Jane's cheek with her finger. Jane manages the ghost of a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MOOR HOUSE - A BEDROOM. Jane is lying back against clean white pillows. Her hair brushed and neatly plaited. Diana and Mary are full of kindness but St John's face is cold, dispassionate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My name is Jane Elliott...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Elliot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you come from, Miss Elliott? Jane gives no answer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who can we send for to help you? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 16.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one. There is an intake of breath from Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you mean to say that you are absolutely without home and without friends?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How did you come to be roaming the moors, Miss Elliott?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't upset her, St John. She must not be interrogated so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rivers, you and you sisters have done me a great service, the greatest man can do - you have rescued me from death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are we to help you if we know nothing about you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll tell you as much as I can. I am an orphan; brought up a dependent; educated in a charity school where I passed six years as a pupil and two as a teacher. I left a year since to become a private governess -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A good situation, where I remained until...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Diana, didn't I say so? Didn't I say she was a governess?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We did wonder. We mean no offence but you have a certain look. Mary and I work as governesses too. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 17.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (with great interest) Do you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are currently trying to teach ourselves German, so we may find better positions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not working at present?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We came home only for our father's funeral.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He died three weeks ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am very sorry to hear it. St John has no patience with the change of subject.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you leave your place of employment? Jane sinks back in the pillows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: ... It was a catastrophe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What did you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am free from any blame, sir. I was happy. Jane is deeply distressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's enough for now, St John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must rest, Miss Elliott. The name sounds strange to Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you start?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because that is not my name. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 18.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You haven't given us your real name? Jane shakes her head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I must not ever be found. Diana and Mary glance at each other, fascinated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. MOOR HOUSE - THE BEDROOM Jane is dressing herself. She stops, weakly holding the back of a chair for support, looking out of the window at the sun setting over the hills.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Merciful Jesus, enlighten thou me with the brightness of thine inward light...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. MOOR HOUSE - THE STAIRS Diana is helping Jane down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) And take away all darkness from the habitation of my heart...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. MOOR HOUSE - THE PARLOUR St John is praying over Jane, Diana and Mary as they sit at the table. Mary catches Jane's eye, gives her shy smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Join me to thyself with an inseparable band of love... For thou, even thou alone, dost satisfy him that loveth thee... Jane finds herself staring at St John, who prays ardently.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And without thee all things are vain and empty. Amen. St John opens his eyes and looks searchingly at Jane. She immediately looks down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Amen. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 19.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Welcome to our table, Miss Elliott.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd appreciate it if you called me Jane. It is my own name.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's wonderful to see you on your feet, Miss Jane. Jane turns her attention to St John.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I trust I will not be eating long at your expense, Mr Rivers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wish to be independent of my charity?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish to work, sir. Show me how to work or how to seek work; that's all I ask.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not fit enough to work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My sisters have always taken pleasure in keeping injured birds but I'm more inclined to put you in a way of keeping yourself - and shall endeavour to do so, if that's what you wish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With all my heart, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's a shame she has no choice of helpers, St John, and must put up with such crusty people as you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This school you were at, Miss Elliot, this charitable institution; what did it prepare you for?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We see a bundle of sharp twigs come down on a girl's bare neck, like a whip.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 20. Jane flinches at the memory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Was it a thorough education?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most thorough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. LOWOOD - THE HALL. Miss Scatcherd's bitter life is in her face and voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Burns, Helen Burns! Jane, aged ten, looks up. She is wearing a brown stuff frock with a puritanical cap like all the other girls. Silence reigns in the school hall. A red haired girl of about thirteen stands up; Helen Burns. Miss Scatcherd holds up an apron in which a hole has been mistakenly cut.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a slattern and a disgrace! Helen Burns undoes the back of her dress. The punishment is given; a dozen sharp, stinging whacks with the birch twigs. Jane is appalled. But to her astonishment and awe, Helen Burns doesn't cry; she barely changes her expression. As the strokes go on - seven, eight, nine - Helen seems like one in a trance. Jane is deeply affected. On the eleventh stroke, the door bursts open and a visiting party walks in: the Brocklehurst family. Miss Temple escorts two young girls dressed in peacock finery and two smart, bombastic ladies. Mr Brocklehurst follows. Helen's punishment is forgotten as the students rush to their feet. Jane, in a panic, drops her slate and breaks it. Brocklehurst's eyes sweep the room. They land on her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I might have known. The new girl. Step forward, Jane Eyre. Filled with dread, Jane steps forward.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is my duty dear children, to warn you that this girl is not one of God's own lambs. We see the look of frustration on Miss Temple's face. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 21.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is a castaway and an alien in his flock and you must be on your guard against her. For this child... is a liar! He points to a tall stool. Jane stands on it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the pedestal of infamy - and you'll remain upon it all day. You'll receive no sustenance and no comfort, for you must learn how barren is the life of the sinner. Children, I exhort you to shun her, exclude her, shut her out from this day forth. Withhold the hand of friendship and deny your love to Jane Eyre, the liar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. LOWOOD - THE HALL - LATER. The hall is empty but for the small figure of Jane, high on her stool, feeling her isolation like pain. Across the room is the slightly bigger figure of Helen, hunched, the back of her dress still open, the skin on her neck raw. The sun is setting. At last Jane starts to sob.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come now, don't cry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not allowed to speak to me. I must be shunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Brocklehurst is not a God. He's not liked or admired here -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He said I was a liar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am not a liar!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If your own conscience approves you, then so will I. Jane is deeply gratified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you bear it? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 22.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bear what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Being struck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a trial to Miss Scatcherd. She hits me to improve me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If she hit me I would get that birch from her hand and break it under her nose.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd just be punished even more. It's part of life here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have always been excluded and alone and hated. Miss Abbott used to call me an ugly little toad. Helen approaches Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not ugly. Do you know what is inside you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The spark of your spirit, the principle of light and thought, pure and bright, as perfect as anything created.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What do you mean?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your soul. Your soul is beautiful, your soul has value - more value than anything on earth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that true?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. God sees your beauty. Even as you stand on that stool, there is an invisible world around you, a kingdom of spirits. It is everywhere. Angels see your pain. Angels know your innocence. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 23.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Angels? Helen smiles a wide smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you not believe in angels? They hear the door. Helen runs back to her place; cowers. Miss Temple appears in a shaft of light at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come here, Girls. The girls approach, dreading more punishment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shall investigate Mr Brocklehurst's claims against you, Jane. And unless they are proved, you will be exonerated. Miss Temple looks over her shoulder.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Also, I understand you girls have had no food today. She quickly presses a slice of hard cake into each girl's hand and walks away. Jane and Helen look at one another, deeply moved by her kindness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MOOR HOUSE - THE GARDEN / MOORS. Jane stands between Diana and Mary high above Moor House. They are dressed similarly in bonnets and cloaks. They watch a hawk dive, their heads moving in unison. Their eyes land upon Moor House.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've lived here all our lives but the house must be shut up now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can't afford to keep it on. Diana and I will return to our charges in a few days and St John will go to his parsonage. Down below them, St John leaves Moor House and walks towards the village. Jane watches him. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 24.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It'll be a hard parting for us. We may not see him again for years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why ever not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He means to be a missionary. He's going to India to do Gods's work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can he not do God's work here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This quiet parish will never do for him; he almost raves in his restlessness. It breaks our hearts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John burns with talents and ambition. But he lacks the means for advancement here. Our poverty thwarts him at every turn and so he has chosen to lay all his gifts on God's altar.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've tried to persuade him to stay but in some things our brother is - he is -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Inexorable as death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are now without father. We'll soon be without home and brother. Jane feels a powerful compassion for them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: In one thing you are fortunate. She looks over at the horizon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. LOWOOD - THE GROUNDS. SPRING. Jane is looking at the high wall which is the horizon of her world at Lowood. Her eyes come to rest on the main door. Two men are carrying a small coffin out of the school. Brocklehurst follows it with a menthol-soaked cloth over his mouth and nose. He becomes aware of Jane's eyes on him. He looks away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 25.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. LOWOOD - THE DORMITORY. Jane is creeping down a corridor in her night dress. She peers in through the dormitory door. It has been turned into a sanitarium. Camphor and vinegar are being burnt. Jane can hardly look at the sick girls. Miss Temple, pale with exhaustion, is speaking intimately to Madame Pierrot, the French mistress. Jane overhears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is the result of semi- starvation and neglected colds; Brockelhurst's idea of mortifying their bodies to save their souls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Temple can't say more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Write to the governors. You must. Jane creeps on.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. LOWOOD - MISS TEMPLE'S ROOM. Jane opens the door. A small bed has been set up at the foot of Miss Temple's. In it lies Helen Burns. A candle is set on a table at her side. Jane takes her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Helen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is it you, Jane? Have you come to say goodbye?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm very happy. I am going home.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Back to your father?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My father has a new wife. He'll not miss me much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then where?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To my future home, where all is light. I am going to God. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 26.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No... Jane is devastated. She climbs into bed next to Helen. For a moment, they hold each other. Jane's tears silently fall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be sad. I will escape great suffering by dying young.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't have any talent to make my way in life. I should be always at fault. But God is my friend. He loves me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then he must save you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is saving me. Jane cannot articulate her distress at Helen's words.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I feel like I could sleep now. I like to have you near -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I won't leave you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're so warm and alive. Jane, you have a passion for living.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. LOWOOD - MISS TEMPLE'S ROOM. We see Miss Temple looking down at the bed in the dazzling, morning light. Jane, waking, has her small arms around Helen, as if fiercely protecting her. Helen is ashen, her eyes open, staring at some unseen thing. She is dead. Miss Temple lifts Jane away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane... Jane realises what has happened. We hear the sound of her distress begin. She is inconsolable.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no, no -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Jane? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 27.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MOOR HOUSE - THE PARLOUR. Jane is staring out at the Autumn rain. She surreptitiously wipes her tears away and smiles up at Mary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you something for me to do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are doing something already. May I see? Jane hands her a book. She has drawn a bride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's Miss Temple on her wedding day. She was my teacher; a great influence on me. Under her guidance I became a teacher too. Mary turns the page. It shows a sketch of St John Rivers. Mary gasps in delight. She takes the book straight to St John, who is diligently working at his desk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, Mary, please -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: See how skilled Jane is. St John looks at the sketch of himself. He is quite taken aback. He looks over at Jane, who is quite embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is better than any drawing master we have ever had. For a moment, St John seems to be weighing up whether to be insulted or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How fierce I am, Miss Elliott.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rivers, I wondered if you had yet heard of any work that I could do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I found you a situation some days ago but I've delayed telling you because the work is lowly and I fear you'll scorn it. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 28.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I shan't mind what I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As I am poor and obscure, the help I can offer is of the meanest sort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John, what are you going to offer her? Not washerwoman, I hope?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When I took over the parish two years ago it had no school. I opened one for boys; I now intend to open one for girls. The school mistress will have a two-roomed cottage paid for by local benefactors and she will receive fifteen pounds a year. You can see how humble, how ignoble it is. On the contrary, Jane is deeply gratified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rivers, I thank you heartily and I accept with all my heart.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you comprehend me? It's a village school - cottagers daughters. What will you do with all your fine accomplishments?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will save them until they are wanted. They will keep. Jane smiles at him. St John is impressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MORTON - THE SCHOOL ROOM. Jane is at the blackboard in a freshly painted school room. In front of her are about twenty village girls, aged from six to sixteen. They are hanging on her every word. Jane is writing a neat line of 'a's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MORTON - JANE'S COTTAGE. Jane's first home is like a doll's house. She walks through it from the whitewashed bedroom with its little single bed, through the parlour with its tiny fireplace into the scullery kitchen. She retraces her steps back into the parlour. She turns round and surveys it. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 29. Silence but for the crackling of the fire and the blowing of the wind. She feels glad, grateful, but very, very alone. She hears Brocklehurst's voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hear you are to leave us, Miss Eyre. She spins around as if he is there.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A CHURCHYARD. Brocklehurst is at the church door; Jane looking at him coldly. She holds a bunch of wild flowers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. Excuse me. She walks into the graveyard. There are over forty small graves marked with wooden crosses, each bearing a child's name. One of them says Helen Burns. Jane lays down her flowers. She looks up at Brocklehurst. He cannot meet her eye. We hear the voice of Mrs Fairfax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) If Jane Eyre of Lowood School...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MORTON - JANE'S COTTAGE. Jane tries to quell her great unhappiness. She springs into action, straightening her furniture, stoking her fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ...Who advertised in the Yorkshire Herald, possesses the acquirements mentioned...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A ROADSIDE. Jane, younger and more hopeful, with her belongings in a small trunk, awaits an approaching public coach.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ...And if she is in a position to give satisfactory references, a situation can be offered where there is but one pupil, a little girl under ten years of age and where the salary is thirty pounds a year. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 30.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MORTON - JANE'S COTTAGE. Jane is in her scullery putting all her energy into scrubbing dishes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Jane Eyre is requested to send references and all particulars to Mrs Fairfax at Thornfield Hall. Jane closes her eyes, trying to banish her thoughts. It is no good. The memories crowd in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE GROUND FLOOR. A smiling lady dressed in black approaches her through the darkness - Mrs Alice Fairfax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you do, my dear? What a long and tedious journey you must have had of it. John is quite the slowest driver in the county. You must be cold to the bone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you Mrs Fairfax?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Indeed I am; come and warm yourself in here. Mrs Fairfax leads Jane up the dark corridor and into a cosy parlour. Leah, a young maidservant, follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your poor hands must be quite numb; here, let me help you. Mrs Fairfax undoes the ribbon on Jane's bonnet. Jane is taken aback, unused to motherliness of any kind.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Leah, make a little hot port and cut a sandwich or two. Leah eyes Jane with great curiosity. She hurries away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Draw nearer the fire. John is taking your trunk up to your room. Knitting apparatus lies abandoned on a fireside chair. Mrs Fairfax moves it and gestures for Jane to sit. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 31.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've put you at the back of the house; I hope you don't mind. The rooms at the front have much finer furniture but they are so gloomy and solitary I think. Jane can't help noticing that every surface is covered in lace, embroidery, or fine crochet. The whole room is an advertisement for Mrs Fairfax's skill at handicrafts - and testament to the hours she has spent alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm so glad you are come. To be sure this is a fine old house but I must confess that in winter one can feel a little dreary and alone. Leah is a very nice girl and John and Martha good people too, but they are servants - and one cannot talk to them on terms of equality.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I to have the pleasure of meeting Miss Fairfax tonight?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Fairfax - my pupil?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh you mean Miss Varens; Mr Rochester's ward. She is to be your pupil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is Mr Rochester?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, the owner of Thornfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought Thornfield Hall belonged to you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (bursting into laughter) Oh bless you child, what an idea. To me? I am only the housekeeper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 32.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is a distant connection between Mr Rochester and I - his mother was a Fairfax - but I'd never presume on it. Heavens, me, owner of Thornfield? She continues to laugh. A bashful smile is playing on Jane's lips. Mrs Fairfax is beginning to thaw her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE HALL / STAIRCASE. Mrs Fairfax is carrying a lamp across the great hall; the only light. Jane can perceive grandeur looming out of the darkness; Jacobean fireplace, coat of arms, head of a stag. Very gloomy, eerie. Her breath is vaporising in the cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shall have a cheerful house this winter... As Jane follows Mrs Fairfax up the stairs, light is thrown on portraits of dour, craggy, long dead ancestors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Miss Varens here - and with you - we'll have quite a merry time of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - A LONG GALLERY. Dark heavy drapes, another striking portrait. A dark, voluptuous woman in an 18th Century gown, ruby lipped, one full breast exposed. Jane glances away, taken aback by the woman's bold expression and her nakedness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm sure that last winter - and what a severe one - if it didn't rain it snowed and if it didn't snow it blew a gale - last winter I declare that not a soul came to the house from November to February. Mrs Fairfax leads Jane through the wood-panelled darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got quite melancholy night after night alone. When spring finally came I thought it a great relief that I hadn't gone distracted. She opens the door to a small but delightful room. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 33.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. Jane looks in: a fire burning, a lamp lit by her bed, a soft quilt, pale chintz curtains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is utterly speechless. Her eight years of physical discomfort and hardship are over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night, my dear. I hope you'll be comfy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Mrs Fairfax can see how affected she is - and how hard she is trying to button it down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NEXT MORNING. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM. Jane opens the curtains. She draws her breath in at the sight of the grounds. They are beautiful.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE DRAWING ROOM. Jane enters a magnificent room. Mrs Fairfax is dusting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What a beautiful house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rochester's visits here are always unexpected. He doesn't like to arrive and find everything all swathed up, so I keep it in constant readiness. Now, come and meet Miss Varens. Did I mention she was French?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE LIBRARY. Adele Varens, an exquisitely dressed child of eight, is chatting animatedly to Jane and Mrs Fairfax. At her side is Sophie, her nurse - a desperately shy and lonely girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sophie has been crying because no one understands. Nobody can speak to us except for Mr Rochester and he has gone away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 34.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Would you ask her about her parents? Mr Rochester's neglected to tell me anything about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you live Adele, before you came to Thornfield?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With Maman - but she is gone to the Holy Virgin now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her mother has passed away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Maman used to teach me to dance and say verses. When gentlemen came to see her I used to dance for them or sit on their knees and sing. May I sing for you now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well - that would be lovely. (To Mrs Fairfax) Adele is going to show us her accomplishments. Adele adopts a lovelorn pose. She sings an operetta song; a forsaken lady plotting vengeance on her lover. Her high voice warbles with pretended emotion. The effect is rather weird. Jane and Mrs Fairfax watch, open-mouthed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How very French...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - MRS FAIRFAX'S PARLOUR. Adele's song continues as a voiceover. Mrs Fairfax is finishing a shawl. Jane is showing Adele pictures of little objects that she has sketched. Adele names them in English. The song ends. Jane gives Adele a sketch of herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Me! It is me! Mrs Fairfax shakes out the finished shawl and puts it round Jane's shoulders, departing before Jane can protest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. For you. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 35. Jane is delighted at the kindness of the gift.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE LONG GALLERY Jane holds a candle, the shawl around her; the moaning sound of a gale outside. She holds her candle up to the portrait of the voluptuous woman. She stares at it curious, both as a girl and as an artist. She brings the candle close, to see how the brushwork has achieved the effect of flesh. She hears a low, knowing laugh in the darkness behind her. She is startled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's there? Her own huge shadow is the only thing that moves. She hears the laugh again. She follows it through the darkness, alert with fear. A door clicks shut at the end of the corridor. To her relief Jane sees Mrs Fairfax approach with a lamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who sleeps up here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one. This part of the house is quite empty, except for you and me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard someone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't have done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A laugh. Someone laughed. Mrs Fairfax flounders for a second.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh - that must be Grace Poole. She likes to sit up here with her sewing. Rather an eccentric soul. (She shouts sharply) Grace? Grace! A door opens. Jane sees a broad-faced woman with slow, intelligent eyes. She looks as if she has just woken up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Eyre has heard a laugh. Grace looks at Jane with sly curiosity. She leaves the sewing room and opens a door through which a flight of steep steps are revealed. Grace climbs them and disappears. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 36.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE LEADS. Jane is on the turreted roof, looking up at the cawing rooks - and down at the view; a white, frosted wilderness. Jane senses a presence behind her. She quickly turns. Mrs Fairfax is coming through the rooftop door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I might find you up here. I've been waiting to pour our tea.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not in need of tea, thank you. Mrs Fairfax approaches, concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, child? You've been here three months now and I'm worried that the position is not enough / to occupy your -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Mrs Fairfax, no. I'm so thankful to be at Thornfield. Please don't think I'm so ungrateful as to be discontented.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But it's a quiet life, isn't it? This isolated house; a still doom for a young woman... Jane looks out at the view once more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish a woman could have action in her life, like a man. It agitates me to pain that the sky- line over there is ever our limit. I long sometimes for a power of vision that would overpass it. If I could behold all I imagine... I've never seen a city, never spoken with men. I've never even seen a town of any size. And I fear my whole life will pass, without ever having... Mrs Fairfax's troubled look makes Jane fall silent. Mrs Fairfax looks as if she is about to say something - then puts on her practical face, the moment of intimacy gone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well now - exercise is a great cure for anything, they say. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 37.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have some letters to post; will you take them?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A FROZEN MEADOW. Jane is walking with purpose, carrying a bundle of letters. The exercise is lifting her spirits. The sun is sinking, turning the frost gold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A FROZEN WOOD. A brook runs close to the path; half frozen. Its slow trickle is the only sound to be heard. Jane moves slowly, acutely aware of everything around her. Further into the wood, the brook has frozen right across the path. Jane slips on it as she passes. The noise of her feet echoes. She steadies herself. She gazes at a huddle of snowdrops, their heads bowed. A crystal drop of water runs to the end of a snowdrop and begins to freeze as she watches. It is held suspended as if the whole winter is contained in it. The moon is mounting the sky. Jane hears a sound like the beating of wings. The blood is rushing through her ears. Her trance is broken by the figure of a great dog - which glides past her so close it almost knocks her off her feet. The beating is loud; not wings she realises, but the rush of an approaching horse. It is almost on top of her before she can move. Her shocked, pale face, her black garments startle both horse and rider.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the deuce - The rider gets the horse under control and continues, only to have his horse slip on the ice. Both man and horse fall with a crash. The dog begins to bark, until the hills echo with the sound. The horse is on one side; the man is lying, trapped beneath it on the ice; Edward Fairfax Rochester.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hellfire. Jane is confounded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pilot, get down! GET DOWN I SAY!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I do anything, sir? Rochester stares at her; a tiny black figure, surrounded by darkening frost, the low moon behind her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 38.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back. Jane doesn't move. Rochester turns to his horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mesrour. Mesrour. With much stamping and clattering, the horse clambers to its feet. Rochester seems relieved. He tries to stand himself. His ankle will bear no weight. He lets out an involuntary cry. It echoes:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Damnation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you injured, sir? Rochester looks at her once more. He manages to get himself off the ice. He sits on a nearby stile. Jane approaches him. She now has the moon on her face. She begins to look less like a phantom and more like a girl.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you are hurt and want help I can fetch someone from the village. I'm on my way there to post a letter. Rochester looks as if he doesn't believe her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where do you come from?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thornfield Hall.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Whose house is that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rochester's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you know Mr Rochester?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I've never seen him. Rochester is trying to place her. She is a puzzle to him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're not a servant there...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am the governess, sir. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 39.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The governess. (A slow smile) Deuce take me, I had forgotten. Examining Jane once more, he laughs a low laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The governess. Jane does not like to be laughed at.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you got an umbrella I can use as a stick?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then try to get hold of his bridle and lead him to me. Jane doesn't like his imperious tone. She looks at the horse; huge, trampling, nervous. Rochester is amused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you would be so kind... Jane obeys. She endeavours to catch the bridle but the horse rears away. Jane falls on the ice. Rochester bursts out laughing. Jane picks herself up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Perhaps it would be easier to bring me to the horse. Come here. Jane resists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me. I must beg of you to come here. Jane approaches. Rochester instantly leans all his weight on her. She almost crumples under it; the first time she has ever touched and been touched by a man. She holds him up. And walks him closer to his horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mesrour. The horse approaches him. Rochester calms it. He springs into the saddle, grimacing as he wrenches his sprain.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. (He bows.) Now, make haste with your letter. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 40. Rochester's spurred heel makes the horse start and rear. Jane steps back. The horse bounds away, the dog rushing in its traces. All three disappear. Jane doesn't move until the sound of hooves has faded away. Her face is flushed, her eyes glitter in the dark.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE FRONT ENTRANCE/HALL. Jane runs up to the front door. She pushes it open. To her amazement, there is a fire burning in the stone fireplace. The whole hall is lit. The double doors are open into the library. Mrs Fairfax is hurriedly approaching.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rochester is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go and change your frock; he wishes to meet you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to change?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes - I always dress for the evening when Mr Rochester is here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But all my dresses are the same.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must have one that is better? He's in a terrible humour; the doctor has been. His horse fell in Hay lane and his ankle is sprained. Mrs Fairfax anxiously hurries back into the library. A large dog wanders out. Jane finds herself looking at Pilot. She smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE LIBRARY. Jane enters. Rochester is in front of a superb fire - one foot bandaged and supported on a stool. Pilot is at his feet - and so is Adele, gazing adoringly at him. Rochester is looking through Jane's portfolio of sketches and watercolours. Jane feels utterly exposed - as if her diary is being read. Mrs Fairfax timidly interrupts. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 41.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here is Miss Eyre, Sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (Without looking up) Let her sit. Jane sits. Rochester continues to study her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have examined Adele and I find you've taken great pains with her. She's not bright, she has no talents - yet in a short time she's made much improvement. Adele is gazing at him uncomprehending, her face radiant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've been resident here three months?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And from whence do you hail; what's your tale of woe?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pardon?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All governesses have a tale of woe; what's yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was brought up by my Aunt, Mrs Reed of Gateshead, in a house far finer than this. At ten years old I went to Lowood school where I received as good an education as I could hope for. I have no tale of woe, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are your parents?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dead.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you remember them? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 42.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And why are you not with Mrs Reed of Gateshead now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She cast me off, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I was burdensome and she disliked me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lowood; that's a charity school, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How long did you survive there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eight years.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No tale of woe...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I daily thank providence for sending us Miss Eyre. She's a kind and patient teacher and an invaluable / companion -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't trouble yourself to give her a character. I'll judge for myself. She began by felling my horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have her to thank for this sprain. Mrs Fairfax looks at Jane, bewildered. Rochester lifts one of her watercolours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adele has brought me these; are they yours? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 43.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. A swollen sea. A cormorant, a golden bracelet held in its beak. A girl's arm coming out of the water, white and deathly, her drowned figure underneath.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where did you get your copies?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Out of my head.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That head I now see on your shoulders?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir. He turns the next. The top of a hill. An expanse of twilight sky. Rising up, a girl's shape, her forehead crowned with a star, red hair flowing; Helen Burns.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The evening star. Rochester gives her a direct gaze.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you bewitch my horse? Jane cannot reply.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE NURSERY. Jane is by the blackboard, where she is writing sums.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tonight I will have my cadeaux. He always bring me a cadeaux. Mrs Fairfax breathlessly enters.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sorry to disturb. He's asked for your art. Jane looks at her in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What for? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 44.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He wishes to have it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To show to his company, I should think. Is this it here? Thank you. Jane watches helplessly as Mrs Fairfax takes her portfolio.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE HALL/LANDING. Jane is crossing the landing holding Adele's hand. Downstairs, the library doors swing wide open. The sound of male laughter can be heard; gentlemen walk out into the hall. Rochester follows, walking with a stick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monsieur! All eyes turn upon the landing. Jane tries to find a shadow to back into but there are none. Adele curtsies.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ah, there she is... It is unclear whether he is referring to Adele or Jane. He makes a bow. The men are staring at Jane with great curiosity. It makes her uncomfortable. She tugs Adele away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE DRAWING ROOM. A box tied with ribbons sits on the table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Ma boite, ma boite! Rochester is leaning against the mantelpiece, drinking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take it away you genuine daughter of Paris and amuse yourself with disembowelling it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We'll open it together, shall we? Mrs Fairfax kindly leads Adele away. Jane is about to cross the room with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Eyre. Sit there. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 45. He gestures to a chair by the fire. Jane obeys. She studies Rochester. He is intent on Adele, who is pulling a pink satin dress out of the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not fond of children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Ciel! Que c'est beau!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nor do I particularly enjoy simple-minded old ladies. But you might suit me - if you would.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: By distracting me from the mire of my thoughts. Adele, irrepressible, runs across the room embracing the dress. She drops on one knee at Rochester's feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Monsieur, je vous remercie mille fois de votre bonte... She looks up, seeking his approval.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is how Maman used to say, is it not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Precisely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let's try it on, shall we? Adele skips off with Mrs Fairfax.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And that is how she charmed my English gold out of my English breeches pocket. Rochester notices how keenly Jane is observing him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your gaze is very direct, Miss Eyre? D'you think me handsome?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No sir. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 46. Rochester laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was too plain; I beg your pardon.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What fault do you find with me? I have all my limbs and all my
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rochester, it was a blunder. I ought to have replied that beauty is of little consequence -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you stick a knife under my
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have other qualities, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just so; other qualities... When I was your age I was a felling enough fellow. I might have been insulted then. You're blushing Miss Eyre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And though you're not pretty any more than I am handsome, I must say it becomes you. (HE LAUGHS) And now I see you're fascinated by the flowers on the rug. Jane senses his mockery.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd like to draw you out. Come, speak to me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What about, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The choice of subject is entirely yours.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How can I introduce a subject when I don't know what'll interest you? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 47.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The fact is, Miss Eyre, I don't wish to treat you like an inferior.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yet you'd command me to speak?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I probably have a right to be a little abrupt and exacting on the grounds of my superiority in age. There must be twenty years between us and a century's advance in experience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't think you have a right to command me just because you're older. Your claim to superiority depends on the use you've made of your time and experience.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've made indifferent use of both. And this is why I sit, galled by my own thoughts - and order you to divert me. Are you very hurt by my tone of command? Jane smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are few masters who'd trouble to enquire whether their paid subordinates were hurt by their commands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes... paid subordinate; I'd forgotten the salary. Well on that mercenary ground, will you consent to speak with me as my equal - without thinking that the request arises from insolence?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd never mistake informality for insolence, sir. One, I rather like. The other, nothing free born should ever submit to - even for a salary.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Humbug. Most free-born things would submit to anything for a salary. But I mentally shake hands with you for your answer. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 48.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not three in three thousand schoolgirl governesses would have answered me as you've just done.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've clearly not spent much time in the company of schoolgirl governesses. I'm the same plain kind of bird as all the rest, with my couple of accomplishments and my common tale of woe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I envy you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your openness, your clear conscience, your unpolluted mind. If I were eighteen I think we truly would be equals. Nature meant me to be a good man, one of the better kind and as you see, I am not so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you a villain then, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a trite commonplace sinner, hackneyed in all the dissipations that the rich and worthless try to put on life. (HE SIGHS) When I was your age, fate dealt me a blow. I was - cursed with a burden to carry through life. I lacked the wisdom to remain cool and I turned desperate. Dread remorse, Miss Eyre. It is the poison of life. Rochester takes in her open, compassionate face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And since happiness is denied me, I've a right to get pleasure in its stead. And I will get it, cost what it may.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you'll degenerate still more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you preaching to me? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 49.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm reminding you of your own words; remorse is the poison of life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But, Miss Eyre, if the pleasure I was seeking was sweet and fresh; if it was an inspiration; if it wore the robes of an angel of light... what then?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't know. To speak truth, I don't understand you at all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My heart has long been a charnel house. Perhaps it'll transform into a shrine.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, I find the conversation has got out of my depth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're afraid of me because I talk like a sphynx.
direction.name: direction
