direction.raw_text: I'm not afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes you are.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've simply no wish to talk nonsense.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you did it would be in such a grave, quiet manner that I would mistake it for sense. Do you never laugh, Miss Eyre? This question cuts Jane to the quick.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only rarely, perhaps. But you're not naturally austere, any more than I'm naturally vicious. I can see in you the glance of a curious sort of bird through the close set bars of a cage: a vivid, restless, resolute captive. Were it but free, it would soar. Cloud high. Jane opens her mouth to speak - but she cannot. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 50.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE GROUNDS. SPRING. Jane is playing battledore and shuttlecock with Adele. Her playing is full of energy, very free. Her cheeks looks almost rosy. It is spring.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just as it turns to come down - that's when you hit it. Adele serves. The game continues apace. Rochester wanders out of the open double doors of the library. He watches. Something lands at his feet. A rook's feather. He looks up at the battlements. A shape disappears, too fast to see. Rochester's features cloud over with an expression of shame and detestation. He stands in a terrible inner conflict. Jane notices him - she misses her shot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mademoiselle has got to rest.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I start to win!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have mercy, Adele. Play with Pilot for a while. Rochester is leaning over the balustrade, his head bowed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is our game disturbing you, sir? He looks up. A hard and cynical expression has mastered his countenance, something resolute. Jane is taken aback.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the contrary. I like your game. I like this cold, hard day. I like Thornfield. Rochester picks up the black feather. He starts to walk across the grounds at a fast pace. Jane follows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've been arranging a point with my destiny, Miss Eyre. My destiny stood up there by that chimney, like one of the hags who appeared to Macbeth. 'You like Thornfield?' She said. 'Like it if you dare'. Well, I dare. It's felt like a plague house for years - He turns, the whole house now in his sights. He shouts: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 51.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But Thornfield is my home and I shall like it! Adele is running after them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mademoiselle - Il faut jouer - Rochester snaps at her with shocking ferocity.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back! Keep at a distance child, or go in! Adele's face crumples into tears. Rochester sees Jane's shock at his outburst. He walks away. Jane isn't sure whether she has been dismissed or not. Adele has run back to Pilot. Jane watches her. She suddenly finds Rochester is back at her side. He walks her along.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's the daughter of an opera dancer, Celine Varens. Celine was a beauty and she professed to love me. Her ardour was so great that, ugly as I am, I believed myself her idol. So I installed in her in a hotel, gave her servants, gowns cashmeres, diamonds - in short, I was an idiot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To fall in love, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've never felt love, have you Miss Eyre? Your soul still sleeps.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're still floating gently in the stream of life, unaware of the rocks ahead waiting to dash you to pieces.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Were you dashed to pieces, Mr Rochester?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not by Celine. How can one ever truly love a woman one has paid for? (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 52.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It ended when I visited her unexpectedly one night and caught her with her handsome, charmless lover. I overheard her waxing lyrical on all my defects - she was mercenary, heartless, senseless. The whole intoxication fell away like a dream. I left her money to support the little French floweret over there, whom she swore blind was mine. I see no proof of my grim paternity in her features; I think Pilot is more like me than she.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you took her on? Adele is curled up, seeking comfort from the dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Some years later, I heard that Celine had abandoned the brat, disappeared to Italy and left it destitute. So I lifted it from the mud and slime of Paris and brought it here, to grow up clean in the wholesome soil of an English country garden. My one good work in a sea of countless sins. Jane is looking at Adele full of compassion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You listen, Miss Eyre, as if it was the most usual thing in the world for a man like me to tell stories of his opera-mistresses to an inexperienced girl like you. Adele? Adele looks up. Rochester speaks graciously.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me; for keeping Miss Eyre from your game for so long. Adele is immensely gratified by his apology.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DUSK. THORNFIELD / THE RED ROOM. Jane, aged ten, is walking along the long gallery. She opens a door and finds herself in the Red Room. She stares into the mirror, searching the pale face of her reflection, as if trying to find an answer. A murmur seems to come down the gaping chimney; a woman's deep sigh. Jane's throat tightens with fear. Something moves in the shadows behind her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 53. She scans them, her eyes full of terror. Jane knows beyond all doubt that something is there. She hears a low laugh. It seems to be right next to her. She tries to scream -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - SECOND FLOOR. Jane wakes. Her curtains are open; moonlight spilling in. She hears it again; the laugh from her dream, right outside her door - low and deep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's there? Footsteps run away. Jane springs out of bed and pulls the door open. A door shuts at the end of the corridor. There is a single candle burning in its holder on the rush matting, flickering in the draft. Jane picks it up. She notices something else - a curling wreath of grey smoke. She follows its trail through the pitch darkness. It is coming thickly from a half-open door at the front of the house - Rochester's. Jane rushes in. Rochester's bed is on fire; the hangings, the curtains, all are alight. The flames are leaping. Rochester is asleep. She shakes him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wake up! Wake up! Sir! Rochester only stirs. The smoke has stupefied him. Jane pulls the burning sheets off - then stops; he is naked. She takes his basin and douses the bed - soaking him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is I, Jane Eyre, sir. Jane takes the ewer and throws water on the curtains. She pulls the soggy fabric from its rail and smothers the burning couch. When all the flames are out, she rushes to the windows and opens them. Smoke billows out. She stands in the moonlight, coughing. Rochester is sitting up, staring at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What in the name of all the elves in Christendom have you done with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For heaven's sake get up. Somebody has plotted something; you must find out who. I'll light the lamp - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 54.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Light the lamp at your peril. Rochester is springing out of bed. Jane turns away, mortified - having caught sight of his silhouetted shape.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I heard a laugh outside my door loud enough to wake me. I opened it. Someone was running towards the third floor. Rochester is putting on a dressing gown, lighting the lamp.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And a candle was left burning in the middle of the floor. Shall I fetch Mrs Fairfax, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What the deuce can she do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I'll wake John and Martha.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. Stay here. You're shivering. Rochester gets his coat and puts it round her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have to go to the third floor. Don't make a sound. Sit there. I shan't be long. He goes. Jane looks at his ruined chamber; The blackened drapes on the four poster bed, the fireplace, the huge wardrobe. It is not unlike the red room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - ROCHESTER'S ROOM. Half an hour later. First light. Jane is in an armchair. She has snuggled up in the coat. She takes in a breath, smelling its owner. She nuzzles her head against it. She closes her eyes, running her fingers down the lining. She looks up. Rochester is watching her. His expression is peculiar. She holds the coat closely around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you see anything when you opened your chamber door?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only the candle on the ground. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 55.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you heard a laugh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you heard that laugh before?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There's a woman who sews here; Grace Poole - She laughs in that way, I think.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just so. Grace Poole - you have guessed it. Well, you're no talking fool; please say nothing about this.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will account for this state of affairs. Go back to your room and say nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, sir. (She takes off his coat) Good-night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is that how you're going to leave me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You said I should go. Rochester approaches her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, fire is a horrible death. You have saved my life. Don't walk past me as if we were strangers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What am I to do then, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At least... shake hands. Rochester holds out his hand. Jane takes it. They shake. Rochester wraps Jane's hand in both of his. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 56.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a pleasure in owing you my life.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There is no debt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I knew you would do me good in some way. I saw it in your eyes when I first beheld you. Their expression did not - did not strike delight into my very inmost being so, for nothing. People talk of natural sympathies... You. Rochester is drawing her slowly closer. Jane, disconcerted, is trying to resist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night then, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you will leave me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go. At last, he relaxes his grip. She backs away. She goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. THORNFIELD. JANE'S ROOM. Jane is keeling on the windowsill, looking out at the rising sun. She is lit by its glowing rays; inspired. It's a rare feeling that prompts her mood, as new and unfolding as the day itself - happiness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - ROCHESTER'S ROOM. Jane looks in to see Leah and Martha cleaning the soot from the woodwork and windowpanes. To her amazement, Grace Poole is there, calmly sewing rings to new curtains.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good day to you, miss.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's happened here?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only master reading in his bed last night. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 57.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fell asleep with his candle lit and the curtains got on fire. Managed to put it out with the water from his stand. Did you not hear anything, miss?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I did. I heard a strange laugh.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's hardly likely the master would laugh when he was in such danger. Perhaps you were dreaming.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you didn't think of opening your door and looking out? Jane is infuriated. She turns on her heel.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - MRS FAIRFAX'S PARLOUR. Jane walks in. Their meal is laid out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Has Mr Rochester not sent for us today?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, he's gone away. Were you not aware? He left after breakfast. Jane takes this piece of news like an invisible shock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's gone to The Leas, Mr Eshton's place, about ten miles from here. I believe Blanche Ingram is there. She's a great favourite of his.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I saw her two years ago when Mr Rochester had a party here. Oh, she was a beauty; I daresay the most elegant girl I've ever seen. So tall, with raven hair cascading down her back; I don't know how she'd had it done. She sang a duet with Mr Rochester. They made a lovely harmony. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 58.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was quite surprised he didn't make a proposal. Perhaps that is his intention now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE NURSERY. Jane is at the window, brooding. Outside the rain is pouring. Adele, dressed in yellow frills, is concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Qu'avez vous mademoiselle?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (without looking at her) Nothing. Speak in English, please. Jane turns, expecting to see Adele.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MORTON - THE SCHOOL ROOM. Jane finds herself in front of her class. They are looking at her expectantly. She looks back at them curiously. Eager faces, plain rural clothes. She has quite lost her place.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, girls. You may go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. MORTON - THE SCHOOL ROOM. Jane is tidying up at the end of the day. The classroom is empty. Her life is bare. It shows on her face. She looks up. St John Rivers is watching her from the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you find the work too hard? Jane immediately puts on a sprightly face and continues clearing up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. I'm getting on very well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you feel the solitude an oppression?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I hardly have time to notice it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then perhaps your accommodations have disappointed you. They are in truth scanty enough - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 59.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A few months ago I had nothing. I was wretched. Now I have a home and work; free and honest. I wonder at the goodness of God and at the generosity of my friends. St John approaches her; speaks intimately.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What you had left before I met you, I don't know. But I counsel you to resist firmly every temptation to look back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's what I mean to do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We can overcome every kind of human weakness. A year ago I was myself intensely miserable. I considered my life was so wretched that it must be changed - or I would die. After a season of darkness and struggling, light broke. I heard my call from God. Put your trust in him, Jane. Let him lead you to your future.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. St John is turning to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why were you intensely miserable?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A year ago, I was weak enough to fall in love. Jane moves involuntarily towards him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't pity me; I have no compassion whatsoever for you. I regarded this love as a fever of the flesh; not a thing that would ever touch my soul. I scorned the weakness, fought hard against it - and won. Jane is incredulous. St John is at her desk. It is covered in her drawings. He glances through them. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 60.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could have listened to temptation, sunk down in the silken snare and known a feverish and delusive bliss. I could have squandered my future upon it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You could have been happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A slave in a fool's paradise? I'd rather my life had purpose - St John suddenly snatches up a piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this yours?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. His eyes, in an instant, seem to take in everything about her. He opens his mouth to speak - then checks himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What's the matter?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nothing in the world. He folds the paper and takes it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night. He goes. Jane looks after him, puzzled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE HALL. Mrs Fairfax approaches Jane with a letter in her hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's back in three days he says - heavens that's Thursday - and not alone. He gives directions to prepare all the best rooms. I'm to get more staff from the George Inn. The ladies will bring their maids, the gentlemen, valets. We must accommodate them all. Supplies to be got; linen, the
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Fairfax has worked herself up into quite a panic. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 61.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll get started. I'll go to the George. No, I'll tell Martha... Jane can sense that the old lady is overwhelmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I assist you, Mrs Fairfax? We see Mrs Fairfax approach Jane in a rush of gratitude.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE SECOND FLOOR. Jane wears a housekeeper's apron over her dress. She enters Rochester's room with an armful of bed linen. It has been returned to its former glory. Adele is jumping up and down on the bed. Sophie is trying to coax her off it. Jane gives Sophie the sheets. Adele leaves the room with Jane and skids all the way down the newly polished gallery in her stockinged feet. Jane can't help smiling.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE KITCHENS. Jane sets down several bottles of wine on the kitchen table in order to dust them. The kitchen is a hive of activity - except for one lone figure sitting quietly in a chair by the fire, smoking a pipe; Grace Poole. Leah and one of the hired under cooks are talking abut her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She gets good wages, I'd guess?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wish I had as good; not one fifth what Mrs Poole receives. Jane affects not to listen, but is keenly interested.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And she's laying it all by. I shouldn't wonder if she's saved enough to keep her independent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's a good hand, I daresay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not everyone could do it, that's for sure, not even for the money.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No wonder the master relies on
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 62. Leah notices Jane's curious glance. She nudges the under cook. Jane, picks up the bottles and carries them away. As she passes she hears:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doesn't she know? At that moment, Adele rushes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're here! They're here! Mrs Fairfax tries to get her apron off. She becomes flustered. Jane helps her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Mrs Fairfax and Adele go. Jane looks out of the window. Her attention is focussed on two equestrians who lead the arriving party; Rochester and Blanche, the dark beauty at his side. She is laughing at something. The sun shines behind her. Jane is dazzled. She turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE SECOND FLOOR. Jane comes up the back stairs and on to the gallery, just as the ladies start to issue from their rooms. She stands back in a dark corner. There is an approach of chatter; a subdued vivacity. A flurry of multicoloured silks, lace and velvets go by. They descend the staircase as noiselessly as a bright mist. Jane steps out. She walks right into the path of Blanche Ingram, who is dressed in white. They both startle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, miss. Blanche gives her a look of ice. Rochester is at the top of the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good evening. They both turn. Rochester has seen Blanche, not Jane. He offers her his arm, his gaze full of admiration. Jane sinks back into the shadows.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I? Blanche lays her gloved hand on Rochester's arm, barely touching him. They glide away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 63.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE HALL. Adele and Jane sit on the stairs, listening to Blanche and Rochester sing. Their voices thrill. Jane is trying not to feel. But when Rochester hits an exceptionally beautiful note, she involuntarily closes her eyes. Adele leans into Jane. She is crying.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it, darling?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sing like Maman. Jane, full of compassion, takes Adele back to her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE SCHOOLROOM. Mrs Fairfax enters in a great hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tonight. He wants you both in the drawing room after dinner. Adele leaps up, delighted. Jane is crestfallen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not me, surely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's his particular wish.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He was being polite.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm instructed to tell you that if you resist, he'll come up and get you himself. You needn't stay long. Just let him see you and then slip away. Don't worry; no one'll look at you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE DRAWING ROOM/HALL Jane is delivering Adele into the centre of the company.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: May I present Miss Adele Varens?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bon jour, mesdames, monsieurs. Jane finds it hard to get a proper impression of the guests, as she cannot raise her eyes to look at them. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 64. Adele makes a dainty curtsey - pink frock, hair in ringlets, little lace gloves. In the midst of the crowd is Blanche.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why, what a little puppet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (mutton dressed as lamb) Is this your ward, Mr Rochester?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (English rose; nineteen) What a love of a child. Adele blissfully disappears into a moving sea of dresses. Only one guest is still looking in Jane's direction; Blanche. Her lip curls in distaste. Jane backs into a nearby window seat; always her place of refuge. She closes her eyes. A great Atlantic wave hits the sash window behind her, drenching it with foam and brine. When she opens her eyes, Rochester is in her line of vision, standing out in a crowd of unmanly men. He senses her gaze; glances at her. Jane looks down, pulling her work on to her lap; a beaded purse. She does not lift her eyes from the beads, fully feeling the humiliation of her class - and of her love. Blanche sidles up to Rochester.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought you weren't fond of children?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're right; I'm not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then what induced you to take charge of that little doll? Rochester turns away from Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was left on my hands.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why don't you send her to school?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She has a governess. Jane glances up; sees Rochester's back to her, throws her eyes down, once more. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 65.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should hear mamma on the chapter of governesses. I had half a dozen in my day - all detestable, ridiculous incubi - were they not, mamma?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Did you speak, my lily flower?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said governesses. The reaction is instant.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, don't mention them; the very word makes me nervous! I've suffered a martyrdom from their incompetence and caprice. I thank heaven we're now done with them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have just one word to say of the whole tribe; nuisance. Jane's fingers sew. Only the briefest flash of her eyes towards the company shows her mortification. Blanche has started playing a brilliant prelude on the piano.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We shall have music - and new subject, if you please. Signor Eduardo, what shall it be?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donna Bianca, I give you beauty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beauty? Why there's nothing new to be said. I give you back male beauty. Mamma, what's your idea of male beauty?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My son, of course.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hear hear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, Tedo's quite typical of the young men of today. They're so absorbed in the pursuit of fashion that they've forgotten how to be men at all. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 66.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I say -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A woman who neglects herself is a blot on humanity. But a man should pay no heed to his looks. (Glancing at Rochester) A man should possess only strength and valour. He could be a gentleman or a highwayman. His beauty lies in his power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So a Levantine pirate would do for you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As long as he resembled you. Rochester laughs loudly. Jane is heading for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am serious. To my mind, a man is nothing without a spice of the devil in him. Jane closes the door on Blanche. She breathes in fresh air, nauseous. Blanche's splendid prelude drifts out. Rochester comes into the hall from the other door. Jane instantly bends down and pretends to be tying her shoe.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you leave the room?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am tired, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why didn't you come and speak to me? I haven't seen you for weeks. It would have been normal and polite to wish me good evening.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You seemed engaged, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you been doing while I've been gone?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Teaching Adele.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You look pale. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 67.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am well.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're depressed; your eyes are shining with tears. What's the meaning of this? Jane catches sight of Mrs Fairfax, who is watching them with an expression of unease. Rochester glares at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A gentleman has arrived to see you, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He says he's travelled a long way, from Spanish Town, Jamaica - Rochester seems winded.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And indeed I think he must have come from some hot country because he won't take off his coat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Spanish Town...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Richard Mason. He says you're old friends. I've put him in the morning room. Rochester cannot speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have I done wrong?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not at all. Please tell him I'll see him directly. Mrs Fairfax goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jane - Jane. This is a blow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Can I help you sir? In the drawing room, Blanche's prelude finishes to enthusiastic applause. Rochester has Jane's hand. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 68.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, if all those people came and spat at me, what would you do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Turn them out of the room sir, if I could.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if they cast you out for adhering to me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I should care nothing about it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd dare censure for my sake? Jane is frightened of his passion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: For the sake of any friend who deserved it. Rochester lets her hand go. He steps back. He goes to the morning room. Jane peers through the door, worrying how her last words have given offence. She sees a man rising to meet Rochester; handsome but gaunt and painfully thin. His smile doesn't reach his eyes - as if his soul is not quite his own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fairfax...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Richard. How the devil are you? They embrace, Rochester doing a fine impression of delight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. LOWOOD - THE HALL. Jane is standing on the pedestal of infamy, ten years old. Helen Burns is walking towards her with something in her arms. The rising sun is all around her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He is yours. Jane looks down at the bundle. In it, is a newborn boy. Jane looks up to ask Helen for help. But Helen has gone. Jane alone with her burden, teeters on the stool. The baby starts to cry. Jane panics. The crying becomes deafening, terrifying. It is not a baby's cry but a human scream. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 69.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM/ THE GALLERY. Jane wakes, hearing a savage, sharp shriek of such power and intensity it seems to tear the night in two. Overhead, the sounds of a struggle begin - a deadly one. Jane hears footsteps rush past her door. She starts to pull on her dress. She hears a man's voice from above:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Help! Rochester, for God's sake come! A great stamp on the floor above; something falls with a thud; silence. Jane grabs her candle and leaves her room. The guests likewise are all issuing from their rooms; some with candles, some stumbling into the dark. The gallery is filling with terrified ladies and shocked gentlemen. Their shadows dance grotesquely on the walls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh what is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who is hurt?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where the devil is Rochester? Rochester comes forth from the door at the end of the gallery, holding a candelabra.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm here, be composed. Blanche flies towards him like a banshee.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What awful event has taken place? She embraces him. Rochester patiently removes her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A servant has had a nightmare, that's all. She's an excitable, nervous person and has taken a fit with fright. Jane, the only person behind Rochester, sees by the light of her candle that his dressing gown is trailing blood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now I must see you back into your rooms because until the house is settled, she can't be properly looked after. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 70.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is there anything I might do?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Miss Ingram, ladies, please return to your nests like the doves that you are. You'll take cold for certain if you stay in this icy gallery any longer. The candles flicker and fade as the guests make their way back to their rooms. Rochester sees Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come this way. Make no noise.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE THIRD FLOOR. Rochester stops by a low door. He puts a key in the lock.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Be steady. I need you. He unlocks it. A room hung with tapestries; a four poster bed with its curtains half drawn. One part of the tapestry is hooked up over a hidden door - which lies open to an inner chamber. A dull, sickly light shines out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait. He goes to the inner chamber. A grim laugh greets him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you, Mrs Poole. He locks the door. Jane shudders. He goes to the bed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here. Bring the candle. Jane obeys. Richard Mason is lying, one arm and all the linen soaked in blood. Jane controls her reaction and makes herself useful. Rochester is cleaning the wound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I dying?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She bit me - while the knife was in - Bit me - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 71.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was folly to attempt the interview tonight and alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I thought I might have done some good.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It makes me impatient to hear you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She sucked the blood. Said she'd drain me - like a vampire -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Think of her as dead, dead and buried. Say nothing! Mason is silenced. Rochester puts the bloody sponge into Jane's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am going for a doctor. I must leave you here with him. Sponge the blood away when it returns. Give him water if he wants it. Do not speak to him for any reason. And Richard - on pain of death - do not speak to her. Rochester takes the candelabra. He is gone. Mason is staring at Jane. There is something about the pupils in his eyes that she finds deadly, chilling. She dips the sponge in the bloody water and wipes away the trickling gore. She hears a low moan. She looks over at the door to the inner chamber, aching to know the mystery behind it. Mason makes her start by taking her wrist. He is trying to say something. Jane puts her finger to her lips. She is begging him not to speak.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. THORNFIELD - THE THIRD FLOOR. Rochester and Dr Carter are carrying Mason down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I only wish I could have got here sooner. He'd not have bled so much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, make sure the way is clear. Jane looks out on to the gallery. She is pale, drawn. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 72.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE GROUNDS. A carriage waits. Rochester lifts Mason in to Dr Carter. Jane hands in Mason's great coat. She stands back.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll ride over tomorrow to see how you do. Goodbye, Richard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fairfax - Let her treated as tenderly as may be -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do my best and have done it and will do it! The carriage goes. Jane prepares to go inside but Rochester walks her towards the orchard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, Jane. That house is a dungeon, don't you feel it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems to me a splendid mansion, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is slime and cobwebs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. THORNFIELD - THE ORCHARD. The orchard is a different world; the dawn light illuminating dewy trees. Rochester is silent. Jane is trying to fathom him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will Grace Poole stay here now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh yes, don't trouble your head about her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But sir -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Grace Poole is not the danger. He walks off, pulling the heads off flowers as he passes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You've noticed my tender feelings for Miss Ingram? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 73.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Keep vigil with me again, the night before I marry. For now you've met my lovely one and you know her. She's a rare one, isn't she?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A strapper, a real strapper; big and buxom... He throws a cankered rose across the orchard. Jane manages to articulate her anxiety.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd do anything for you sir, anything that was right.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And if I ever bid you do what was wrong, you'd turn to me, quiet and pale and say 'I cannot do it.' And you'd be as immutable as a fixed star. Rochester, gazing at her, seems to have decided something. He turns a corner and is gone. Jane is left alone. We hear the sound of a blow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE WINDOW SEAT. The brutal face of John Reed, aged fourteen, triumphant after hitting Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's for the look you had on your face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE BILLIARD ROOM. Jane enters as Rochester helps Blanche to line up a shot. He is leaning intimately over her. She coyly permits him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Excuse me, sir. Jane has ruined Blanche's shot. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 74.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Does that creeping creature want you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE LONG GALLERY. Rochester has followed Jane out of the billiard room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you please, I want leave of absence for a week or two.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What to do? Jane shows him the letter.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is from my old nurse, Bessie. She says my cousin John Reed is dead. He ruined himself and has committed suicide. The news has so shocked his mother, my Aunt, that it's brought on a stroke.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What good can you do her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She's been asking for me. I parted from her very badly and I can't neglect her wishes now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Promise me you won't stay long.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, it seems you are soon to be married.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What of it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adele should go to school.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: To get her out of my bride's way who might otherwise trample her?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And I must seek another situation. I intend to advertise. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 75.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: At your peril you advertise. Trust it to me. I'll find you a good situation in time. He is on the point of returning to the billiard room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And sir? Forgive me but I have had no wages as yet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much do I owe you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Fifteen pounds. Rochester looks in his wallet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here's fifty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That's too much.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Take your wages.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I only have a ten.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Now you owe me five.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just so. Come back for it quickly. Meantime, I shall safeguard it in here. He taps the wallet, which is in his breast pocket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you trust me to keep it, Jane?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a whit, sir. You are not to be trusted at all. Rochester strides away, grinning. Jane turns. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 76.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - BESSIE'S PARLOUR. Bessie, now housekeeper, is moving forward to meet Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bless you! - I knew you'd come. They embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Bessie... I'm not too late? How is Mrs Reed?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She may linger yet a while. She's spoken of you daily. At first we couldn't tell what she was saying but when her speech came clear we heard 'Jane Eyre, get Jane Eyre.'
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Shall I see her now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll take you up directly. But look at you. What a lady you've become. Why you're almost pretty.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - MRS REED'S BEDROOM Jane takes her aunt's hand. Mrs Reed looks very near death.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Aunt Reed? It is Jane Eyre. You sent for me, and here I am. Mrs Reed, with an effort, pulls her hand away from Jane's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No one knows the trouble I have with that child. Such a burden. Left on my hands. Speaking to me like a fiend. The fever at Lowood. She should have died!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why do you hate her so?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Her mother. Reed's sister - his beloved. When news came of her death he wept like a fool. Sent for the baby. Sickly thing - not strong like mine. But Reed loved it. Kept it by his bed. Made me vow to bring the creature up. Why did he not love mine? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 77. The words are a revelation to Jane. Mrs Reed gazes at her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who are you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am Jane Eyre, Aunt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You. Is there no one in the room? Jane motions Bessie to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are alone.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've twice done you wrong. I broke the vow I made to Reed -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, don't think of it -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am dying; I must get it out! Mrs Reed indicates a box on her bedside table.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Open that box. Take out the letter. Read it. Jane obeys. She reads the letter aloud.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: 'Madam, will you have the goodness to send me the address of my niece, Jane Eyre. I desire her to come to me at Madeira. Fortune has blessed my endeavours and as I am childless I wish to adopt her and bequeath her at my death whatever I may have to leave. Yours, John Eyre, Madeira.' Jane is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is dated three years ago. Why did I never hear of it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I wrote and told him you had died of typhus at Lowood school. You fury. You were born to be my torment. I'll never forget how you turned on me and raged. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 78.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You called the names of the dead down upon me. I was afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You cursed me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would have loved you if you'd let me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My life has been cursed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, let us be reconciled. Mrs Reed shrinks from Jane's touch. Jane wipes her tears.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then love me or hate me as you will. You have my full and free forgiveness. Now ask for God's - and be at peace. Mrs Reed's eyes close.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. GATESHEAD - THE RED ROOM. The morning sun is pouring in. Jane goes to the bed. She puts her hand upon it, gently, as if thanking her uncle for all he did. She notices a picture on the wall. A miniature of a brown-haired woman with elfin eyes. Jane takes it off the wall. Bessie comes in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother. Bessie nods. A tear rolls down Jane's face. She clasps the picture, looking round the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why ever was I so afraid?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A ROADSIDE. A coach pulls up in the lane near Thornfield. Jane gets out. We hear her voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) My dear uncle, some years ago, my Aunt Reed mistakenly informed you that I had died. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 79.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. A SUMMER WOOD. Jane is walking through the wooded glade where she first met Rochester. All is green and verdant and bathed in sunset light. There seems to be life everywhere.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) I am writing to tell you that I am very much alive and living at Thornfield Hall, where I am currently governess to the ward of Mr Edward Fairfax Rochester -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) There you are. Jane turns. Rochester is sitting on the stile where they first met. For a moment, her every nerve is unstrung.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Just like one of your tricks to steal into your home along with the twilight. Where the deuce have you been this last month?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have been with my aunt sir, who is dead. Rochester laughs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A true Janian reply. If I dared I'd touch you, to see if you were real... Jane puts out her hand. Rochester takes it. He helps Jane over the stile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Go home - stay your wandering feet at a friend's threshold. Jane lets go of his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you Mr Rochester. I'm strangely glad to get back again to you. Wherever you are is my home. Jane, knowing she has said too much, turns and runs over the fields towards Thornfield.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - MRS FAIRFAX'S PARLOUR Jane is on a low seat, Adele nestling close to her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 80.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We're expecting the announcement very soon. He went down to London only last week to buy her a new carriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then we must accept it. He'll soon bring home his bride. Mrs Fairfax nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . THORNFIELD - THE ORCHARD Jane is alone, drinking in the beauty of the evening - looking at the gardens as if she may never see them again. She turns a corner and sees Rochester staring intently at something. His back is to her. She is about to tiptoe away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come and look at this fellow, Jane. Jane approaches, wondering how he has sensed her presence. Rochester is looking at a huge moth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Look at his wings. He looks West Indian - I have never seen one like him, here. There; flown. They watch the moth as it flies towards the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thornfield is a pleasant place in summer, isn't it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll be sad to leave it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, but it can't be helped. I soon hope to be a bridegroom.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you found me a new situation, sir?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A situation, yes of course. It's the least I can do for a faithful paid subordinate such as yourself. You're to undertake the education of the five daughters of Mrs Dionysus O'Gall of Bitternut Lodge, Connaught. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 81.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Connaught?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll like Ireland. They're such warm-hearted people, they say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is a long way away, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: From here. From you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We've been good friends, Jane haven't we? But with the Irish sea between us you'd soon forget me. Jane's great distress escapes her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wish I could. I wish I'd never come here. I love Thornfield - I've lived a full life here. I've not been trampled on or petrified or buried with inferior minds. I've talked face to face with what I reverence, with what I delight in. I've known you Mr Rochester -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then why must you be torn from me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because of your bride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have no bride.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you will have.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, I will.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I must go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must stay.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think I could stay to become nothing to you? Am I an automaton, a machine without feelings? (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 82.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you think that because I am poor, obscure, plain and little that I am soulless and heartless?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have as much soul as you and full as much heart. I'm not speaking to you through mortal flesh. It's my spirit that addresses your spirit as if we'd passed through the grave and stood at God's feet, equal - as we are. Rochester takes Jane in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As we are. Jane struggles away from him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm a free human being with an independent will, which I now exert to leave you. Rochester releases her. She stands in front of him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then let your will decide your destiny. I offer you my hand, my heart and a share of all this. He gestures towards the house, the land. Jane is stunned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I ask you to pass through life at my side. Jane, you are my equal and my likeness. It is you I intend to marry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you mocking me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you doubt me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Entirely. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 83.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have no faith in me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not a whit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You little sceptic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your bride is Miss Ingram -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What love have I for Miss Ingram? What love has she for me? I caused a rumour to reach her that my fortune was lost and got instant coldness. I wanted to make you jealous, to move you to love me. It's you - you strange, unearthly thing. I love you as my own flesh. You - poor and obscure as you are - please accept me as your husband. Jane begins to believe him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you in earnest?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must have you for my own.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wish me to be your wife?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I swear it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You love me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then sir, I will marry you. They embrace. Neither Jane nor Rochester moves. Darkness is almost complete. Still the intensity of the embrace is held.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It will atone. It will atone. A sheet of lightning momentarily lights up the sky. Some moments later a distant rumble of thunder. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 84.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE FRONT HALL It is teeming with rain. Rochester and Jane run to the front entrance. He holds his jacket around her. Lightning. They reach the dry hearth inside. Thunder. They are both euphoric, breathless, laughing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night. Good night. He kisses her. They kiss again. Jane will not let him go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night. As Jane runs upstairs she sees Mrs Fairfax, deeply shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - MRS FAIRFAX'S PARLOUR Jane wears a lilac gown. Mrs Fairfax is very concerned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Have you accepted him?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well I never would have thought. Jane is hurt.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I a monster? Is it so impossible that Mr Rochester should love me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, I've long noticed that you were a sort of pet of his. But you're so young and so little acquainted with men. I don't want to grieve you child, but let me put you on your guard. Gentlemen in his position... Let's just say they're not accustomed to marry their governesses. Until you are wed, distrust yourself as well as him. Please, keep him at a distance - Jane has heard enough. She turns away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 85.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE HALL Jane, walking through, finds herself in Rochester's arms. She laughs as he raises her off the ground.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is this my pale elf? This sunny faced girl with the radiant eyes?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is I, Jane Eyre sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Soon to be Jane Rochester.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It can never be, sir. Human beings were not meant to enjoy complete happiness on this earth. It's too much like a fairy tale.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let the fairy tale begin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A HABERDASHER'S SHOP. Rochester is rolling out reams of beautiful silks. Jane gets more uncomfortable as she looks at them.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This morning I wrote to my banker in London to send certain jewels. In a day or two I hope to pour them into you lap -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, no sir -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I will put the diamond chain around your neck myself -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I don't want jewels -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll dress you in these satins -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you won't know me. I'll not be Jane Eyre any longer but an ape in a harlequin's jacket. Put them away. Jane pushes the silks away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 86.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well for cool native impudence and pure innate pride, you haven't your equal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm naturally proud. And hard and flinty. You ought to know what sort of bargain you've made while you've still got time to rescind it. I want only one thing from you, Mr Rochester.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And what's that?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your regard. Jane puts her arm through Rochester's. He smiles.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's your time now, little tyrant but it'll soon be mine and when I have seized you, to have and to hold, I'll attach you to a chain, like this... Rochester flicks his watch into the air.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - MRS FAIRFAX'S PARLOUR. A summer gale. The moan of the wind sounds almost human. The light is sickly, nightmarish. A great box sits on the table, which Jane is opening. Adele, Sophie and Mrs Fairfax are all looking on. Jane pulls out a pearl coloured wedding gown. She is dismayed at its opulence. She holds it up to herself. Adele starts to play with the great veil. She wraps it round herself. She becomes caught in it, tangled, distressed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adele? Jane wakes. There is a candle alight at the end of her bed. Her eyes focus. Her wardrobe is open. Jane is unnerved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Adele, is that you? Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 87. A form emerges, a woman, tall and gaunt, with thick, black hair hanging down her back. She is dressed in a nightgown - like a shroud. Over her head, she wears Jane's bridal veil; a phantom bride. Jane is paralysed with terror. The form takes the veil and slowly tears it in half; bruised arms, dirt, predatory nails, neglect. The last thing to be revealed is the woman's face, pale and ghastly. Her eyes are glittering with hatred. The figure takes the candle and bends down to Jane. Her intention looks deadly. Jane's breath catches. She cannot breathe. The figure moves closer, then blows out the candle. Darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM. Jane wakes, lying half out of the bed. The veil is over her. She flings it away from her face. Jane sits, her terror dawning. Her breath comes in great dry sobs. She is shocked to find herself still alive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. - THORNFIELD - BY THE GATES Jane is waiting, pale with anxiety. A man on horseback approaches, a great dog at his side; Rochester. He is grinning. He pulls Jane up on the horse in front of him. She curls into his arms, desperate for his comfort and his strength. Rochester senses something is wrong. He slows the horse.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What is it?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm afraid.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM. Rochester holds the torn veil in his hands. He is aghast. He cannot think what to say.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, this is the only explanation. It must have been half-dream, half- reality. A woman did enter your room last night and that woman was - must have been - Grace Poole - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 88.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It was not Grace Poole. Rochester keeps talking over her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You know how strange she is. What did she do to me? To Mason? In a state between sleeping and waking -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was not asleep.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You noticed her entrance and her actions but you've ascribed to her an appearance different from her own. That was your nightmare -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know what I saw.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I see you'd ask why I keep such a woman in my house. When we've been married a year and a day, I promise I'll tell you. Are you satisfied Jane? Do you accept my solution? Jane clearly doesn't. Rochester takes her in his arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dear God. It was only the veil...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - ADELE'S ROOM. Jane is in an unadorned pearl wedding gown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mademoiselle... Adele gives her a small bouquet. Jane hugs her, very moved - as if she is leaving her childhood behind. She turns to go.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please, you must look. Jane gazes stupefied at the stranger in the mirror.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE HALL. Rochester is waiting at the bottom of the stairs for Jane. She slows when she sees him. She finds she cannot speak. Neither can he. Mrs Fairfax is by the door. Jane can't find words for her. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 89.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come. Rochester grips her hand. They quit the house.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE GROUNDS. Rochester, grimly resolute, is striding at a pace Jane can hardly follow. Her satin shoes are muddy. She is becoming breathless. A rook flies over their heads, cawing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE CHURCH. Rochester is striding purposefully towards a small church of ancient design. Jane stumbles. Rochester is contrite. Jane tries to collect herself. She looks up to the sky. The rook wheels around the spire. She takes Rochester's hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THE CHURCH At the altar, Jane glances at Rochester. He is looking straight ahead at the clergyman, Wood.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I require and charge you both, as ye will answer at the dreadful day of judgement when the secrets of all hearts shall be revealed, that if either of you know any impediment why ye may not be lawfully joined together in matrimony, ye do now confess it. There is not a sound. Rochester still doesn't look at Jane. The clergyman prepares the rings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward Fairfax Rochester, do you
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A commotion at the back of the church. Two men rapidly enter. One of them Briggs, hurries up the aisle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The marriage cannot go on. I declare the existence of an impediment. Rochester moves, shaken.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Proceed. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 90.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ceremony is quite broken off. An insuperable impediment to this marriage exists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Proceed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rochester has a wife now living. Wood is utterly dismayed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is your proof? Briggs starts to read out a document.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) I affirm and can prove that Edward Fairfax Rochester was fifteen years ago married to my sister, Bertha Antoinetta Mason at St James church, Spanish Town, Jamaica. Jane looks at Rochester. She forces him to look at her. He denies nothing; defies everything.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The record of the marriage will be found in the register of that church - a copy of it is now in my possession. Signed, Richard Mason. Rochester turns to Briggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That does not prove that my wife is still living.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She was living two months ago.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How do you know?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I have a witness to the fact.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Produce him or go to hell. The figure by the door steps out of the shadows. It is Richard Mason. Rochester flies down the aisle, a groan of rage escapes him. He lifts his arm. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 91.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good God -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, you are in a sacred place - Mason flinches away. Rochester swallows his rage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you to say?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: She is at Thornfield Hall. I saw her there in April. I'm her brother. A grim smile contorts Rochester's lips. He turns towards Jane. She remains where she was abandoned - at the altar - tiny, under he vaulted arch. The bouquet falls from her hand. Rochester walks to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This girl knew nothing. She thought all was fair and legal. She never dreamt she was going to be entrapped into a feigned union with a defrauded wretch. A tiny breath is the only noise Jane utters. Rochester pulls her from the altar to his side.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come, Jane, come all of you and meet Mrs Poole's charming patient. Come and meet my wife. The sun outside is blinding. Jane closes her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE ENTRANCE / HALL Rochester enters pulling Jane after him, her hand still in his iron grip. Wood, Mason and Briggs follow. Mrs Fairfax, Adele, Sophie, Martha and Leah are waiting. Adele runs forward. Rochester stops her in her tracks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Get back! Do not come near! Go, all of you - keep your congratulations - they come fifteen years too late! Adele has crumpled into frightened tears. Mrs Fairfax has her hand over her mouth, pale with shock. Jane meets her eye as Rochester pulls her up the stairs. A revelation. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 92.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE THIRD FLOOR. The tapestried room. Rochester glances at Mason. He unlocks the inner door with one hand; the other won't let go of Jane. Grace Poole sits by a strongly guarded fire, stirring something in a pot. Rochester leads Jane and the men into the room. There is no window, no furniture except for Grace's chair; only a mattress on the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir, you can't be bringing folk in here. It's madness. Bertha Antoinetta Mason stands, amazed at the sight of her visitors. She wears a white shift. There are black rook feathers twined in her hair; her only ornament.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This clothed hyena is my wife. Bertha's pose is dignified, her expression grows triumphant. She approaches Rochester - her eyes locked with Jane's. Jane gazes: fear, disgust, compassion.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was duped into marriage with this lunatic fifteen years ago. Briggs and Wood are deeply repelled.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let us go. We have seen enough. Bertha puts her arm through Rochester's; lays her head on his shoulder; smiles at Jane, magnanimous in her victory.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My own demon, Bertha. With shocking speed and strength Bertha lays her nails into Rochester's cheek. He struggles with her. Grace assists Rochester. They do not hit; they subdue. Bertha's attack is effectively contained. They have her on her knees, her arms behind her. Bertha lifts her head and screams. If a scream could express the agony of a whole soul then this would. Jane turns on her heels. She stumbles, finds the door, exits.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE SECOND FLOOR. Jane is coming down the stairs. Briggs is at her side. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 93.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You, madam, are clearly not to blame. Your uncle will be glad to hear it. Jane looks at Briggs, only dimly comprehending him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You wrote to your uncle, did you not? To inform him you were going to marry Mr Rochester? Mr Mason was staying with him when your letter came. Briggs gets only a blank look of puzzlement from Jane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr John Eyre has been the Madeira correspondent of the Mason trading house for some years. You can imagine his distress when Mason revealed the real state of matters. Jane starts walking towards the sanctuary of her room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He would have come himself but I'm sad to tell you that his health is in mortal decline. He implored Mr Mason to prevent this false marriage and referred him to me for assistance. I only hope that he survives long enough to hear that you are safe. Jane opens her door. She turns to Briggs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Thank you. She shuts the door on Briggs and on the world.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM. Jane sits on her bed. She mechanically starts taking off the blond square she has worn as a veil.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, standing in stillness with the pearl dress crumpled around her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 94. Jane has taken a black stuff dress off its hangar. She slowly puts her arms around it, as if it is her old self. She holds it, her eyes staring at nothing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane in her underclothes, sitting down on the bed. She closes her eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. A DRY RIVER BED. Jane lies curled up on a rock at the bottom of a dried-up river bed. All of nature is suspended in stillness. Far away, we hear the sound of a flood loosened in the remote mountains. We hear the sound of the torrent approach. Jane doesn't move. She has no will to flee. The sound of rushing water pounds in her ears. She lies, waiting to be dashed away. We see the flood approach and hit. A dazzling whiteness of water and foam.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM. Jane's room is entirely unchanged except for the fact that it is full of river water from floor to ceiling. Her bedding, furniture and belongings all sit in the room as normal - underwater. The light shines murkily in through the window to reveal Jane floating, suspended. Her hair and her garments trail out. She is alive. But she is drowned.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - JANE'S BEDROOM. The moon has risen. Jane is lying in an exhausted doze on the bed. She wakes; sits up. She is faint. She recovers herself. She knows what she must do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, dressed in black in the silver light, putting her brush, comb and brooch in a bag. She looks in her purse. She has some coins.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - SECOND FLOOR. Jane unbolts her door, takes a step out of her room, and stumbles into Rochester's arms. He has been keeping guard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 95. His cheek has been cut by Bertha's nails.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Five minutes more of that death- like hush and I'd have forced the lock. He examines her face. He is desperate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No tears. Your heart has been weeping blood. Forgive me. Rochester buries his head in Jane's arms. She automatically comforts him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How could I? I am a worthless sinner. Don't spare me. Rain your tears up on me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I deserve a hail of fire. Jane extricates herself from his embrace.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm tired and sick. I need some water. Rochester perceives Jane's inanition. He carries her down the gallery. Jane clings on to her bag of belongings. She has nothing else left.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THORNFIELD - THE LIBRARY. Rochester has lain Jane in front of the fire. She forces herself to eat. Rochester gives her wine. She sips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How are you now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Much better, sir. I shall be well again soon. Rochester paces away to the fire. He comes back. Stoops his head down to Jane to kiss her. She turns her head away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know you. You are thinking. Talking is no use; you are thinking how to act. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 96.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: All is changed, sir. I must change too.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes. There is no doubt that we both must change. I was wrong ever to keep you here; this narrow stone vault with its one real fiend. I'll shut it up. I'll pay Mrs Poole two hundred a year to care for its inmate and then no one will be harmed when she is prompted to burn people, to stab them, to bite the flesh from their bones -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sir - you speak of her with hate - it is cruel. She cannot help being mad.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's not because she's mad that I hate her. If you were mad do you think that I'd hate you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then you know nothing about me, nothing about the way I love. Your mind is my treasure - and if it were broken it would be my treasure still. You are my sympathy, my better self, my angel. I will wrap my whole existence round you. Let us leave here tomorrow. Come with me - as my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'll pledge you my fidelity -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You can't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'll live a happy, most innocent life -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must leave you, sir. Rochester cannot take this in. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 97.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't you love me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do love you - But I mustn't show it or speak it ever again. I must begin a new existence - strange scenes among strange faces. I must part from you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Must be a part of me; that's what you mean. You are my wife, Jane. In truth -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have a wife already.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was tricked, duped into wedlock with that demon-hate, that harlot, that succubus upstairs. My father wanted her money and so I was sent to Spanish Town and the match was made. I hardly spoke with her. I was dazzled, ignorant, raw. My senses were besotted and I married her - gross, grovelling mole-eyed blockhead that I was. Rochester sits, staring at the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I lived with her for four years. She dragged me through all the degrading agonies which attend those bound to the intemperate and unchaste. Her excesses developed germs of madness and the doctors shut her up. One night, unable to bear her screaming hate and knowing I could never be rid of her, I put a gun to my head to kill myself. Jane is both appalled and moved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would have pulled the trigger, died in that tropical place but for a breeze which blew in from the sea and smelt of home. With it, I came to my senses. Bertha Antoinetta Mason had abused my long suffering, sullied my name, outraged my honour and blighted my youth. It was enough. At that moment, as I decided to live, she ceased to be my wife. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 98.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Only my father and brother knew of the marriage and by then they were both dead. I let my connection with her be buried in oblivion and I brought her here. I have seen that she's cared for as her condition demands and that is all that God and humanity asks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I earnestly pity you, sir. He sees that Jane is silently crying.
direction.name: direction
