direction.raw_text: Jane, it's not pity that I see in your face. It's not pity -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do not say it -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It is love.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They are holding each other.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I was wrong to deceive you. It was cowardly. I should have appealed to your spirit - as I do now - should have opened my life, described my hunger for a better existence - shown you my chains. I give you my life. I give you my pledge. Please, be my wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You would be my equal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would make it so.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You once told me that hiring a mistress is the next worse thing to buying a slave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Not my mistress - Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 99.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would not degrade you by having you live with a slave.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I said wife, my wife - Jane tries to rise. Rochester keeps hold of her hand. He gently pulls her down again. Comforts her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you really mean to leave me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane... He kisses her gently, lovingly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do you mean it now?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I do. He runs his hands over her, with great tenderness. Jane offers no resistance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And now? Jane nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh Jane... Rochester lays her down.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What friends would you offend by living with me? Who would be injured? Who would care? Jane is almost lost. She speaks in a small voice.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I would.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, it would not be wicked to love me...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It would be to obey you. I care for myself. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 100. Jane's resolve grows. She resists.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The more alone, the more friendless, unsustained I am, the more I must respect myself -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you listen to me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must listen to myself -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Will you hear reason?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Let me go -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because if you won't I'll try violence. Jane instantly stops resisting. She looks at him with utter shock. He is above her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I could bend you with my finger and thumb; a mere reed you feel in my hands. Jane neither moves nor speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But your eye; resolute, free. What ever I do with this cage I cannot get at you. And it is you, soul, that I want. Why don't you come of your own free will here, to my heart? Oh come, Jane, come -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God help me! All the life seems to go out of Rochester. He lets Jane go. She pulls herself away from him. She stands. He remains, his face buried. She goes to the door. Rochester turns his eyes to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You have never called me by my name. My name is Edward. Jane cannot speak it. She turns away. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 101.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAWN. THORNFIELD - THE GROUNDS. First light. Jane is running; flushed, breathless, her dress soaked with dew. She has her bag of belongings over her shoulder. She trips; falls to her knees. She looks back. For a moment she seems paralysed. She returns her gaze to the route ahead. Her need to escape is so great that she crawls forwards until she is able to raise herself to her feet. She reaches the stile; lifts herself on to it; puts her arms around the post. She holds it, as if it were beloved. Her eyes close. We hear the sound of a winter blizzard.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. JANE'S COTTAGE. Jane opens her eyes. She is sitting at her fireside. Outside, a snowstorm howls. On her knee is a sketchbook. She looks down at it. Rochester's dark eye is beginning to appear on her paper. She puts a line through it; scribbles it out, blinding him. She stands up, trying to escape her thoughts. She whispers:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Edward. There is a loud knock on the door. Jane starts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane opening the door. Rochester is there, standing in the frozen hurricane and howling darkness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane. Jane pulls him inside. She falls into his arms. They embrace passionately. Jane is actively pulling him towards her, delirious with love and longing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The exact same shot of Jane opening the door. St John Rivers is there, having waded through the drifting snow.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr St John - What on earth brings you away from your hearth on a night like this? Has anything happened? There's no bad news I hope?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How easily alarmed you are. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 102. He takes off his cloak; stamps the snow off his boots.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The snow was up to my waist at one point.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are recklessly rash about your own health.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nonsense. St John's eyes alight on Jane's charcoal drawing. Jane snatches it away too late. There is a moment of silence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why are you come?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: An inhospitable question.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I mean on a night like this -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I got tired of my mute books and empty rooms. Besides I've been told half a story and I'm most impatient to find out the end.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Please... Jane motions to St John to sit. He doesn't. She becomes increasingly uneasy as he speaks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty years ago, a poor curate fell in love with a rich man's daughter and married her. She was disowned by her family and two years later the rash pair were both dead. They left a daughter which charity received into her lap - as cold as that snow drift I almost stuck fast in. Charity carried the friendless thing to the house of its rich maternal relations. It was reared by an aunt-in-law; I come to names now - Mrs Reed of Gateshead. Jane starts. She is on her feet.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mrs Reed kept the orphan ten years and at the end of that time she was sent to Lowood school. (MORE) Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 103.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It seems her career there was very honourable. She became a teacher like yourself, and left it, like yourself, to be a governess. She undertook the education of the ward of a certain Mr Rochester -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rivers! -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can guess your feelings but hear me to the end. Of Mr Rochester's character I know nothing but he professed to offer honourable marriage to this young girl and at the very altar she discovered that he had a wife yet alive. His subsequent conduct is a matter of pure conjecture but when the governess was enquired after it was discovered that she had fled Thornfield Hall and no trace of her has since been found. Now isn't that an odd tale?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Since you know so much, perhaps you can tell me how he is.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Mr Rochester; how is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm ignorant of all concerning him. St John opens his pocket book and removes a piece of paper.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Well, since you won't ask the governess's name, I must tell you. I have it written down here in black and white. He hands her the paper. On it are doodled the heads of some of her pupils. She has absently written Jane Eyre in the margin several times.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A solicitor named Briggs wrote to me of a Jane Eyre. I knew a Jane Elliott. This paper resolved my suspicion into certainty. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 104.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The solicitor - Mr Briggs - does he have any news of Mr Rochester?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Are you not going to enquire why he has gone to such lengths to find you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What does he want with me?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Merely to tell you that your uncle, Mr John Eyre of Madeira, is dead; that he has left you all his property and that you are now rich.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are rich; quite an heiress. Silence. Jane is flabbergasted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your fortune is vested in the English funds; Briggs has the will and all the necessary documents. You can enter on immediate possession. At last, Jane looks questioningly up at him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your forehead unbends at last; I thought you were turning to stone. Perhaps now you will ask how much you are worth.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: How much am I worth?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh a trifle. Twenty thousand pounds - but what of that? The news literally takes Jane's breath away.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Twenty thousand pounds? St John begins to laugh at Jane's reaction. She has never seen him laugh before. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 105.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you'd committed a murder and I'd found you out, you could scarcely look more aghast.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There must be some mistake. It's two thousand, surely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: It's twenty. You look desperately miserable about it, I must say. Jane still cannot take it in. She frowns in disbelief.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did Mr Briggs write to you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You see, that is the strange thing. It makes me wonder what power or providence led you to our door. Your name is Jane Eyre.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Then I'm you namesake. I was christened St John Eyre Rivers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John Eyre -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My mother had two brothers, one was a clergyman, your father, the other was John Eyre of Madeira. Mr Briggs wrote to inform us that the clergyman's daughter was lost. I have been able to find her out; that is all.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Your mother was my father's sister?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: My uncle John was your uncle John?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: That is correct. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 106.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So you, Diana and Mary -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are cousins, yes. Jane is deeply moved.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh, I am glad! - I am glad! She throws her arms around St John. Tears of happiness start to flow. He, finding it peculiar to be held, gently tries to calm her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Here you are neglecting essential points to pursue trifles. You were utterly downhearted when I told you that you were rich and now, for a matter of no moment, you are deliriously happy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Of no moment? You have sisters and maybe don't care for a cousin but I have nobody. I have been alone, always. And now three relations are born into my world full grown. Oh, I am glad. You, who saved my life -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You must try to tranquillise your feelings. Jane finally releases him, still radiant with joy.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Write to Diana and Mary. Tell them to hand in notice and come home. They will have five thousand each and so will you.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've told you the news too quickly. You're confused.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't put me out of patience, cousin. I am rational enough. Twenty thousand divided equally between the nieces and nephews of our uncle, gives five to each.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: This is acting on first impulse. You don't know what it is to have
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 107.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: And you cannot imagine - family - I never had a home. I never had brothers and sisters - A terrible thought occurs to her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are not reluctant to own me, are you? St John takes her hand. She has surprised and moved him. He looks at her, seeing her anew.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, I will be your brother.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. SPRING - THE MOORS. Jane, Diana and Mary are running over the moors. Mary has a kite. They are as delighted as children.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MOOR HOUSE - THE KITCHEN. Jane is sitting at the table letting Diana style her hair. They all have new summer dresses on. There is a lightness to all three as if a great weight has been lifted from their shoulders. Diana is setting Jane's hair into curls like her own. Jane looks at herself in the mirror; softer, gentler, different.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MOOR HOUSE - THE PARLOUR. The girls each have a candle. St John kisses Mary. He kisses Diana.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You call Jane your sister but you don't treat her as such. You should kiss her too. Jane turns to Diana, embarrassed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Di, you are very provoking. As she turns back, she finds St John's face right in front of her. He kisses her. A kiss with no warmth; an experiment. He examines its effect. He is satisfied. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 108.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Good night.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MOOR HOUSE - JANE'S BEDROOM. Jane closes the door. She puts her hand across her lips. The icy kiss has agonised her with the full force of her loneliness. She curls up in a ball, desperate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. MOOR HOUSE - THE GARDEN. A glorious summer sunset. Jane is digging at a flower bed, putting all her passion into the task. She is flushed with exertion. St John watches.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You are wasted here.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Am I not being useful?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You should look beyond Moor House, beyond the selfish calm and comfort of affluence.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Beyond to what?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I go to India in six weeks.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: So soon? - St John draws Jane away from her work.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see what your gifts are and why they were given. Come with me. Jane is utterly crestfallen.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: God and nature intended you for a missionary's wife. You are formed for labour not for love. I want to claim you - not for my pleasure but for God's service.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'm not fit for it. I have no vocation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're far too humble. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 109.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John have mercy. I feel my mind shrinking -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Don't be afraid. You are diligent, faithful, docile, courageous, gentle and heroic. Cease to mistrust yourself. I trust you unreservedly. Let me give you time to think. But know this; in you, I recognise a fellow soul, a soul that would revel in the flame and excitement of sacrifice. Jane is chilled to the bone by his words. St John leaves the garden and walks away over the moors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane leaning against the garden wall, trying to think, trying to compose herself. The sun is setting.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. MOOR HOUSE - THE PARLOUR. Jane carrying a candle, opens the door. St John is at the table working by lamp light. The moon shines brightly in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I used to long for a life of action, to overleap the horizon, to move in the world of men. Maybe God is giving me this. And what is there for me here? Pain and longing for what can't be. I don't know how long I would survive in India. My frame isn't strong. But I'll go with you, if I may go free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Free?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You and I had better not marry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why not?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I am your sister.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: But you'll go with me.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Conditionally - as your curate. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 110.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane, I don't need a curate; I need a wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I must have my heart and mind free, my own self to turn to. I couldn't become part of you -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A part of me you must become or the whole bargain is void. How can I, a man not yet thirty take out to India a girl of nineteen, unless she is my wife? Don't offer God half a sacrifice. He must have all. And undoubtedly enough of love would follow to make the union right, even in your eyes. Jane is shocked.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Enough of love?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Yes, quite enough.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: St John, I scorn your idea of love. I scorn the counterfeit sentiment you offer and I scorn you when you offer it! St John is mortified. A slow rage begins to boil in him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I've uttered nothing that deserves scorn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Forgive me but the very name of love is an apple of discord between us. My dear cousin, please abandon your scheme of marriage.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No; and if you reject it, it's not me you deny but God. Jane is stung. St John has turned from her. His face is icy in the moonlight.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Do not be angry with me please. It makes me wretched. I want us to be friends. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 111.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We are friends. I hope we can be more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I cannot come as your wife.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why this refusal? It makes no sense!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I were to marry you, you'd kill me. You're killing me now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I'd kill you? I am killing you? Your words are violent, unfeminine and untrue -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd kill me without drawing any blood or receiving on your conscience any stain of crime.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What nonsense is this?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You'd experience no pain - but I tell you it would kill me!
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Because I would inevitably come to conceive love for you, because you are so talented and good, because there is such grandeur in your look. You wouldn't want this strange and torturing love; if I showed it you would find it unbecoming. And my lot would be wretched.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: You're a good man, but you forget the feelings of little people. We'd better keep out of your way lest you trample us. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 112. St John's anger has faded. He is compassionate. This is far harder to resist.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I wouldn't trample you. You'd walk at my side towards God's altar. He'd be your solace, heaven your reward. We seek to do the greatest work, to open death's gates, to save souls. Love God Jane, love God. St John puts his hand on her forehead; Christlike. Jane is falling under his power.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Give up your heart to Him. He is love. Jane falls to her knees. St John's face is angelic.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If I were sure; if I were certain - She suddenly hears a voice: Rochester's; clear, urgent.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (O.S.) Jane! Jane! Jane! She springs away from St John, crying:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Oh God, what is it? She looks wildly about the room; rushes to the window.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: What have you heard? What can you see? Jane glances at him, seeing him for what he is; a cold, controlling man. She shouts:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I am coming! She runs out, leaving St John aghast, behind her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . NIGHT. THE MOOR. Jane runs on to the moors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Wait for me! She looks all around her at the moonlit landscape. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 113.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where are you? The moors send her question back in an echo. We see Jane's face. Her path is clear.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. WHITCROSS MOOR. Jane is waiting for the coach at the crossroads where she arrived, almost a year before. It comes pounding towards her. She hails it. This time, the coachman respectfully descends to take her bag and help her on. She is so confident and so changed that he doesn't recognise her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE GROUNDS. Jane is walking through the orchard. It is wild, neglected. Its untended state worries her. She looks up. Rooks are circling, cawing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jane finds herself at the side of the house. The ground is pitted with weeds. The windows are dark. She half runs round to the front. What she sees takes her breath away. The great walls and battlements are blackened with fire. Windows gape on a hollow shell. The inside of the house has collapsed. Through the hanging door, only its charred remains can be seen. Weeds grow through utter devastation. Jane gazes in horror and distress.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MRS FAIRFAX'S COTTAGE Jane knocks on the door. Mrs Fairfax opens it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They sent me from the inn. I've been up at the house - Jane can say no more.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Come in, come in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Is he dead? Mrs Fairfax takes Jane in her arms.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: No, no. Mr Rochester still lives. Jane is crying tears of relief. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 114.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tell me - please -
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why did you run away in the night like that? I would have helped. I would have helped.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MRS FAIRFAX'S COTTAGE Mrs Fairfax has sat Jane on a settle near the fire.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He sought you as if you were a lost and precious jewel. He didn't rest. And as days turned into weeks and no word came, he grew quite savage in his disappointment.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He stayed at Thornfield?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Didn't leave the house...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. THORNFIELD - THE FRONT DOOR/GROUNDS. Rochester, unshaven and unkempt is standing at his threshold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) Shut himself up like a hermit. He only went out at night, when he walked like a ghost through the grounds. We see what he is looking at: an open carriage piled with luggage, into which Mrs Fairfax is helping Adele. Leah and Sophie are already sitting inside, dressed for a journey.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) (CONT'D) He'd have no one near him. Adele was sent off to school. He placed me here. Only John and Martha stayed - and Mrs Poole of course. Adele looks back at Rochester with tears in her eyes. He walks across the dark hall and slams the library doors.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE ORCHARD. Rochester, in his shirt sleeves, is looking at the tree where Jane promised him her hand - now dying, cleft by lightning. The rising moon inhabits the sky. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 115.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) It was harvest time when it happened. No one knows how she got out. Rochester hears a cry from the top floor. He sets off, a look of finality on his face.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE KITCHEN. Grace Poole is asleep, her empty jug of gin beside her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) My theory is that when Mrs Poole was asleep, having taken too much of the gin and water... Rochester takes Grace's keys.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE THIRD FLOOR Rochester opens the door to the inner chamber.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) ... The mad lady must have stolen her keys and let herself out. Bertha Antoinetta Mason, standing in the last patch of daylight thrown down from her skylight, sees that it is Rochester. She calmly walks towards him. Rochester graciously bows, indicating that she may leave. Bertha glides past him. She is free.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE GALLERY Bertha walks past an elegant vase. She tips it to the floor. It smashes. Rochester pays it no heed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE LIBRARY. Rochester has stood Bertha at his desk. A case of jewels is open before her. She has put on a tiara, a diamond necklace, bracelets. She is gazing at a ruby brooch. She turns to Rochester. His expression is calm, resigned. Bertha begins to laugh. She takes the candelabra from the table. She admires herself in the mirror; her white shift, the black feathers, the jewels. She holds up the candelabra and sets the huge curtains alight. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 116. Rochester is impassive; he does nothing to stop her. As she passes, Rochester realises he is bleeding. She has run the brooch pin across him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE HALL/STAIRS. Bertha knocks a lamp onto the floor. The oil springs into flames, licking the tapestries and the paintings. Rochester sees his ancestors begin to burn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE SECOND FLOOR The conflagration is growing. Rochester sees Bertha leaving Jane's room. As he passes, he sees everything inside it being consumed by fire. He can't bear to look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. THORNFIELD - THE LEADS. Bertha is watching the rooks. Rochester goes to the edge of the roof. Bertha looks at him. The invitation is clear. Rochester is ready to die. Bertha sees the rooks wheeling away. She runs at the edge of the roof. Rochester sees her intention too late. He puts out his arm to stop her. For the perfect fraction of a second, Bertha flies. Rochester sees her fall; almost falls himself - saves himself. Life reawakens in him. Behind him, he sees Grace Poole, coughing, crawling up through the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Antoinetta? Responsibility floods over him. He goes to her side, lifts Grace, helps her down the stairs.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: (V.O.) He didn't leave the house until everyone was out. Some say it was a just judgement on him for having her confined there all those years but for my part, I pity him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. MRS FAIRFAX'S COTTAGE Jane is deeply affected.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He's alive child, but many think he'd be better off dead. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 117.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Why?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: When he was taken out from under the ruins, a beam had fallen in such a way as to protect him, partly - but his eye was taken out and his left hand so crushed that he lost it. The other eye inflamed and - he is blind. He's blind. Tears fall from Jane's eyes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I know... it's a terrible thing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I had dreaded worse. I'd dreaded he was mad. A great sense of urgency is coming over her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Where is he?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. FERNDEAN - THE GROUNDS. Jane is walking through forest, along a grass grown track. Her pace is fast; her journey almost at an end. She comes to a pair of rusting iron gates hanging open between granite pillars. She walks through them. She finds herself in front of a decrepit Elizabethan manor house; no garden, just a sweeping semi circle of meadow grass, which someone has cut at with a scythe. Jane stops. Standing on the threshold is Edward Fairfax Rochester. He is in his shirtsleeves. He stands strong, stalwart, brooding. His hair is still raven black. He is looking sightlessly around his domain, with the concentration of a hawk. His strength is undiminished. He walks fifteen paces from the house. It brings him into the middle of the semicircle of grass. He is close enough for Jane to see his scarred eyes. She walks towards him, silent. A few drops of rain begin to fall. Rochester puts out his right hand to feel them. He raises his face up to the sky as if he is looking for something from there. He is absolutely still; his expression, serene. Jane is very close. She steps on a twig. It breaks with a loud crack, shattering the silence. Rochester is immediately on guard, his expression turning wary. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 118. He suddenly swipes the air with his left arm; the ruin of it passing an inch from her face. Jane steps back. Rochester swipes again. She holds her breath. He seems satisfied at last that nothing is there. He turns and walks fifteen paces back to the house. He disappears into the dark interior. Jane starts to breathe again.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . DAY. FERNDEAN - THE SIDE ENTRANCE. Jane lightly taps on the side door. Martha opens it; she is astonished. Jane puts her finger over her lips.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: . EVENING. FERNDEAN - THE DRAWING ROOM. Rochester is in an armchair in front of his fire. Pilot is at his feet. Jane carries in a tray with a candelabra and a jug of water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: I can see the candles, Martha, at your side like a luminous glow. And the fire; a red haze. Pilot notices Jane. He leaps up with a whine, wagging his tail, madly. Jane spills half the water. She cannot help finding it funny. Her entrance has been ruined by the dog.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha? Jane giggles. Rochester's face falls.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha, is that you?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Martha is in the kitchen, sir.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Who's there?
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pilot knows me. Will you have some more water? I've spilt half the glass. Rochester stands, holding out his hand.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: If you are real, touch me. Jane touches his fingers; puts her hand in his. Rochester pulls her into his arms. Jane Eyre adapted by Moira Buffini March 2008 119.
direction.name: direction
